questions.question: Which of the following looks like a good study plan for an average student hoping to earn an average grade of "C" in the course?

options.text: For each topic, first spend ~1 hour doing the assigned reading and going over the handout while looking at the powerpoints for that that topic. Then, watch the recordings for each topic. Next, spend ~30 minutes reviewing the handouts/powerpoints and your notes from the recordings. As soon as possible after completing the above, spend ~1 hour answering study questions on the topic. Later in the week, spend at least 1.5 hours answering study questions or quizzes for all the topics covered up to that time.
options.comment: Yes! However, it should be noted that each student is different and so somewhat different plans may work better for some students.

options.text: Spend a large percentage of your time on reading the textbook.
Spend almost all of your time on the course handouts.

questions.question: Repetition is essential to storing information and concepts in you long-term memory. Therefore,

options.text: it is recommended that you do the assigned reading shortly before watching the recordings. Then, begin answering study questions and reviewing the handouts and your notes within a few hours after watching the recordings, answer more study questions a few days later and again before each exam.
try to learn everything the night before the exam.

questions.neutral_comments: Staying on top of the material will greatly increase your chances of doing well in the course. In addition, going back over the material at strategic intervals will greatly increase the chances that you will not only do well on exams for this course, but will also remember the material for years to come. That means students who get the material into their long-term memories will avoid the time and frustration associated with having to re-learn material, and will therefore likely have an easier time being successful in future biology classes.

questions.question: Which of the following looks like a good study plan for an average student hoping to earn an above average grade of "B" or "A" in the course?

options.text: For each topic, first spend ~1 hour doing the assigned reading and going over the handout while looking at the powerpoints for that that topic. Then, watch the recordings for each topic. Next, spend ~30 minutes reviewing the handouts/powerpoints and your notes from the recordings. As soon as possible after completing the above, spend ~1 hour answering study questions on the topic. Later in the week, spend at least 1.5 hours answering study questions or quizzes for all the topics covered up to that time.

For each topic, first spend ~1 hour doing the assigned reading and going over the handout while looking at the powerpoints for that that topic. Then, watch the recordings for each topic. Next, spend ~30 minutes reviewing the handouts/powerpoints and your notes from the recordings. As soon as possible after completing the above, spend ~1 hour answering study questions on the topic. Later in the week, spend at least 3 hours answering study questions or quizzes for all the topics covered up to that time.
options.comment: Yes! However, it should be noted that each student is different and so somewhat different plans may work better for some students.

questions.question: According to University policy, how many total hours of effort should an average student need to spend each week during the semester to earn a grade of “C” in a 4 credit course, such as BIOL 1009?

options.text: 16 hours per week
8 hours per week
4 hours per week
10 hours per week
12 hours per week
options.comment: Correct! Please note that an average student should expect to spend more than 12 hours per week on the course to earn a grade of “B” or “A”. Correct! Please note that an average student should expect to spend more than 12 hours per week on the course to earn a grade of “B” or “A”.

questions.neutral_comments: For an average student to achieve an average grade in this course, the University Senate expects them to put forth three hours of learning effort per credit per week over a full semester. This means that to earn a grade of “C” in BIOL 1009 (a 4 credit course), a student should expect to spend approximately 12 hours per week on coursework. An average student should expect to spend additional hours of effort to earn a grade of “B” or “A” in the course.

questions.question: Why is it important to spend some time answering study questions within a few hours, and again within a few days, of listening to the recordings for a topic?

options.text: The study questions will disappear from the Canvas site within 24 hours after the date for each topic.
Going over the material within a few hours, and again within a few days, is very important to getting the material into your long-term memory.

questions.neutral_comments: Studies have shown that reviewing the material within a few hours, and then again within a few days and again within a few weeks, is critical to getting the material into your long-term memory. That’s why it is strongly recommended that you start answering study questions within a few hours after listening to the recordings for a topic, again at the end of each week and again before each exam.

The syllabus describes course policies, what to do if you have a documented learning disability, have to miss an exam, etc. The syllabus also lists all the assigned readings for the course, the due dates for each quiz and the dates of the exams.

Remember that you can take each quiz up to three times, so if you take it once and aren’t happy with your score, you can always go back to answering the study questions until you feel prepared to take the quiz a second or third time.

questions.question: How final course grades will be determined

options.text: is on a curve.
will be determined later in the semester.

is described in the course syllabus. The course syllabus describes the number of points that may be earned for each course activity and lists the number of points that need to be earned in order to earn different final course grades.
is a mystery.

questions.neutral_comments: Grades in BIOL 1009 are determined using "guaranteed point cutoffs". This means that every student in the course who earns more than a certain number of points is guaranteed to receive at least a certain letter grade. In other words, the cutoffs will NOT be raised, even if that means that every student earns a final course grade of "A". The course syllabus describes the number of points that may be earned for each course activity and lists the number of points that need to be earned (i.e. the "guaranteed point cutoffs") in order to earn different final course grades. Please note that grades are NOT curved in BIOL 1009. You can download a copy of the course syllabus from the course Canvas page.

Being unavailable due to work, family commitments, vacations, weddings, etc are not valid reasons for requesting a make-up exam.

questions.question:
Scholastic dishonesty, such as cheating on exams or plagiarism, is not tolerated in this course. BIOL 1009 is a required course for almost all students taking it. This means that the information covered in the course is information students will likely need to be successful in their future careers. As a result, committing scholastic dishonesty in this course is not only dis-honorable, but is also likely to negatively impact students' future careers.

Because scholastic dishonesty is not tolerated in this course, students found to have committed scholastic dishonesty, such as cheating on an exam:

options.text: will receive a grade of "0" on the exam or assignment affected by the dishonesty and will be reported to the university's Office of Community Standards.
will be given an opportunity to make up some or all of the points they lost by getting a "0" on an exam or other assignment.
will be given a second chance if they promise not to do it again.

questions.neutral_comments: Integrity is taken seriously in this course. The minimum penalty for students caught cheating or committing some other form of scholastic dishonesty will be a grade of "0" on the assignment or exam in question, with no second chances or opportunities to make up any of the lost points. In addition, 100% of students caught cheating or committing some other form of scholastic dishonesty will be reported to the UMN Office of Community Standards.

questions.question: Why is it a good idea to spend a few minutes reviewing the handout and your notes within a few hours, and again within a few days, of listening to the recordings for each topic?

options.text: Reviewing the material within a few hours, and again within a few days, is important to getting the material into your long-term memory.

That’s why it is recommended that you review the information (go over the handouts and your notes and answer some study questions) within a few hours after watching the recordings for a topic, again at the end of the week and again before each exam.

questions.question: Regarding the online quizzes:

options.text: If you forget the deadline for a quiz, you can take it late
If you are about to submit a quiz right before the deadline and the power or internet goes out (i.e. something happens that was completely outside of your control), you can take the quiz late
If you are sick when a quiz is due, you can take it late

Quizzes must be completed on time, by the dates listed on the last page of the course syllabus. For that reason, each student's three lowest quiz scores will automatically be dropped. That way, if you forget a quiz or your internet quits or something, you will not have to take a zero on a quiz.

questions.neutral_comments: Quizzes must be taken on time by the dates listed on the last page of the course syllabus. Because “stuff happens”, each student's three lowest quiz scores will automatically be dropped. So, if you do miss a quiz for any reason, that quiz will simply count as one of your three dropped quizzes and you won't have to take a zero on that quiz. To avoid missing quizzes, it is strongly recommended that you take each quiz at least once at least a day before that quiz is due. Conversely, it is strongly recommended that you NOT wait until shortly before a quiz is due to attempt it for the first time. Remember, you can take each quiz up to three times with only your highest score counting, so it makes sense to take each quiz at least once a day or two before it's due so it won't matter so much if it slips your mind the day it's due.

questions.question: What are two methods of scientific inquiry?

options.text: hypothesis-based science and experimental planning
experimental planning and theoretical design
discovery science and experimental planning
discovery science and hypothesis-based science

questions.question: An explanation that is broad in scope and is supported by a large body of evidence is known in science as a

options.text: all of these answers are correct
hypothesis
theory
prediction

questions.neutral_comments: Theories are broad in scope; hypotheses are generally narrow in scope. Theories are typically supported by a larger body of evidence than any one hypothesis. Predictions are made based on hypotheses. For example, if your hypothesis is that your phone doesn’t work because the battery is dead, you might make the prediction that re-charging your phone will fix it.

questions.question: The method of scientific inquiry that describes natural structures and processes as accurately as possible through careful observation and the analysis of data is known as

options.text: discovery science.
experimental science.
qualitative science.
hypothesis-based science.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT an example of discovery science?

options.text: Some of Charles Darwin’s work that helped lead to the theory of natural selection
Observations that led to the conclusion that all organism are made of cells
Testing the prediction that mimicking the coloring of poisonous snakes will protect non-poisonous snakes from predation.
Some of Jane Goodall’s work observing chimpanzee behavior

questions.neutral_comments: Discovery science describes natural structures and processes as accurately as possible through careful observations and data analysis. Discovery science does NOT involve formulating hypotheses, making predictions based on those hypotheses and then testing those predictions. That is part of the process followed when doing hypothesis-based science.

questions.question: A theory is

options.text: not correct unless it is several years old
a poorly supported idea that has little backing but might be correct
a concept that, once established in the scientific literature, can be modified but never rejected, even when new scientific methods produce data that don’t fit
a well-supported concept that has broad explanatory power

questions.question: In science, a “theory”

options.text: all of these answers are correct
is broad in scope
tends to generate new hypotheses
is supported by a large body of evidence

questions.neutral_comments: The word “theory” does not the mean the same thing when talking about science as it does when talking about everyday life. In everyday life, “theory” is often used to mean an untested speculation. In science, a “theory” is an explanation that is broad in scope, generates new hypotheses and is supported by a large body of evidence.

questions.question: Quantitative data may be collected

options.text: only when carrying out numerical science
only when carrying out discovery science
only when carrying out hypothesis-based science
when carrying out discovery science or hypothesis-based science

questions.neutral_comments: Both quantitative and qualitative data may be collected when doing either discovery science or hypothesis-based science. Quantitative data are numerical measurements. Qualitative data are not numerical measurements. For example, data showing the precise weights of different dogs would be quantitative data. Data describing how friendly different dogs are would be qualitative data.

questions.question: What types of data may be collected when doing discovery science?

options.text: Qualitative data only
Quantitative data only
Quantitative and qualitative data
Only data that is partially qualitative and partially quantitative

questions.neutral_comments: Both quantitative and qualitative data may be collected when doing either discovery science or hypothesis-based science. Quantitative data are numerical measurements. Qualitative data are not numerical measurements. For example, data showing the precise weights of different dogs would be quantitative data. Data describing how friendly different dogs are would be qualitative data.

questions.question: Discovery science

options.text: focuses on answering specific questions
focuses on testing predictions
focuses on accurately describing natural structures or processes
focuses on formulating hypotheses

questions.neutral_comments: Discovery science describes natural structures and processes as accurately as possible through careful observations and data analysis. Discovery science does NOT involve formulating hypotheses, making predictions based on those hypotheses and then testing those predictions. That is part of the process followed when doing hypothesis-based science.

questions.question: In science, a possible answer to a specific question is know as a

options.text: theory
hypothesis
prediction
all of these answers are correct

questions.neutral_comments: In hypothesis-based science, specific questions are asked based on prior observations or information. The tentative (possible) answers to those questions are known as “hypotheses”. Predictions are then made based on those hypotheses and the predictions are tested. Theories are broader in scope than hypotheses and so are not possible answers to specific questions, although they may be answers to really broad questions.

questions.question: What types of data may be collected when doing hypothesis-based science?

options.text: Quantitative and qualitative data
Qualitative data only
Only data that is partially qualitative and partially quantitative
Quantitative data only

questions.neutral_comments: Both quantitative and qualitative data may be collected when doing either discovery science or hypothesis-based science. Quantitative data are numerical measurements. Qualitative data are not numerical measurements. For example, data showing the precise weights of different dogs would be quantitative data. Data describing how friendly different dogs are would be qualitative data.

questions.question: The process whereby science experts determine whether a manuscript is suitable for publication in a scientific journal is known as

options.text: prediction testing
hypothesis-based science
discovery science
peer review

questions.neutral_comments: During peer review, typically two to three experts in the field read the manuscript and determine whether it is suitable for publication. These experts base their opinion on whether the experiments were done in a rigorous manner, the data carefully analyzed and the interpretations of the data described in the manuscript justified by the data.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of qualitative data?

options.text: The fish swam in a zigzag motion.
The plant's height is 25 centimeters (cm).
The six pairs of robins hatched an average of three chicks.
The temperature decreased from 20°C to 15°C.

questions.neutral_comments: Quantitative data are numerical measurements. Qualitative data are not numerical measurements. All of the possible answers involve numerical data, except for the data describing the fish as swimming in a zigzag motion.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the logic of hypothesis-based science?

options.text: If my hypothesis is correct, I can expect certain results.
If my observations are accurate, they will support my hypothesis.
If I generate a testable hypothesis, tests and observations will support it.
If my prediction is correct, it will lead to a testable hypothesis.

questions.neutral_comments: A hypothesis is a possible answer to a specific question. Predictions are made based on the hypothesis and those predictions are tested (e.g. by carrying out appropriate experiments). Because hypotheses are only POSSIBLE answers to questions, and you will often have multiple hypotheses for each question that you ask, the data you obtain will not necessarily support a particular hypothesis.

questions.question: Qualitative data may be collected

options.text: only when carrying out numerical science
only when carrying out hypothesis-based science
when carrying out discovery science or hypothesis-based science
only when carrying out discovery science

questions.neutral_comments: Both quantitative and qualitative data may be collected when doing either discovery science or hypothesis-based science. Quantitative data are numerical measurements. Qualitative data are not numerical measurements. For example, data showing the precise weights of different dogs would be quantitative data. Data describing how friendly different dogs are would be qualitative data.

questions.question: During peer-review of a manuscript

options.text: typically two to three experts review the manuscript
the conclusions drawn in the manuscript are carefully considered to determine whether they are adequately supported by the data
all of these answers are correct
the experiments described in the manuscript are evaluated to determine whether they were rigorously performed

questions.neutral_comments: During peer review, typically two to three experts in the field read the manuscript and determine whether it is suitable for publication. These experts base their opinions on whether the experiments were done in a rigorous manner, the data carefully analyzed and the interpretations of the data described in the manuscript justified by the data.

questions.question: A hypothesis

options.text: is a prediction scientists make based on many careful observations
is a tentative answer to a question
is the same thing as a theory
is a specific question formulated by scientists after making many careful observations

questions.neutral_comments: A hypothesis is a tentative answer to a question. Ideally, hypothesis-based science is carried out in the following steps: 1) Make observations. 2) Ask a question about those observations. 3) Form one or more hypotheses (= tentative answers to the question). 4) Make predictions based on the hypotheses. 5) Test predictions (e.g. by doing experiments). 6) Determine whether the results of the tests do or do not falsify the hypothesis. NOTE: It is not possible to PROVE that a hypothesis is correct. Instead, depending on the results, tests (experiments) may only show that a particular hypothesis is false.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of qualitative data?

options.text: Records of precise water temperature
Records of cell lengths
Records of plant weights
Recordings of bird songs

questions.neutral_comments: Quantitative data are numerical measurements. Qualitative data are not numerical measurements. For example, data showing the precise weights of different dogs would be quantitative data. Data describing how friendly different dogs are would be qualitative data.

questions.question: A hypothesis must be testable and falsifiable to be scientifically valid. Being testable and falsifiable means that

options.text: there must be several options in the hypothesis to chose from, one of which is correct
only a controlled experiment can prove whether a hypothesis is correct or incorrect
some conceivable observation or experiment could reveal whether a given hypothesis is incorrect
the hypothesis has been proved wrong

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of quantitative data?

options.text: Records of plant weights
Records of which beers taste bitter
Recordings of bird songs
Records of which dog breeds sometimes have black hair

questions.neutral_comments: Quantitative data are numerical measurements. Qualitative data are not numerical measurements. For example, data showing the precise weights of different dogs would be quantitative data. Data describing how friendly different dogs are would be qualitative data.

questions.question: A hypothesis

options.text: can NOT be proven to be correct
can be proven to be correct or incorrect, depending on experimental results
can be proven to be correct
can NOT be proven to be correct or incorrect, regardless of experimental results

questions.neutral_comments: It is not possible to PROVE that a hypothesis is correct. Instead the results of tests (experiments) may only show that a particular hypothesis is false. For example, if your hypothesis for why a flashlight isn’t working is that the batteries are dead, you might predict that replacing the batteries will fix the flashlight. If you then test your prediction by replacing the batteries and find that the flashlight still does not work, you have disproven your original prediction that replacing the batteries would fix the flashlight and have thus shown your hypothesis to be incorrect (false). However, if the flashlight works after you replace the batteries, that finding does not prove that your hypothesis was correct. This is because you can still come up with alternative hypotheses for why the flashlight now works. For example, you could hypothesize that the reason the flashlight wasn’t working previously was because the original batteries were inserted incorrectly. Then, when you replaced the batteries, you inserted the new batteries correctly and so fixed the flashlight. If that is the case, then your original hypothesis that the old batteries were dead would be false. The bottom line is that we can never rule out that there might be a different hypothesis that also explains all of the available experimental results and that is actually the correct hypothesis.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about hypotheses is FALSE?

options.text: Hypotheses should be possible answers to specific questions.
Hypotheses should be falsifiable.
Hypotheses should be testable.
Hypotheses should be provable.

questions.neutral_comments: It is not possible to PROVE that a hypothesis is correct. Instead the results of tests (experiments) may only show that a particular hypothesis is false. For example, if your hypothesis for why a flashlight isn’t working is that the batteries are dead, you might predict that replacing the batteries will fix the flashlight. If you then test your prediction by replacing the batteries and find that the flashlight still does not work, you have disproven your original prediction that replacing the batteries would fix the flashlight and have thus shown your hypothesis to be incorrect (false). However, if the flashlight works after you replace the batteries, that finding does not prove that your prediction was correct and thus does not prove that your hypothesis was correct. This is because you can still come up with alternative hypotheses for why the flashlight now works. For example, you could hypothesize that the reason the flashlight wasn’t working previously was because the original batteries were inserted incorrectly. Then, when you replaced the batteries, you inserted the new batteries correctly and so fixed the flashlight. If that is the case, then your original hypothesis that the old batteries were dead would be false.

questions.question: Through careful experimentation or observations, it is possible to prove

options.text: a theory, but not a hypothesis
either a hypothesis or a theory
a hypothesis, but not a theory
neither a hypothesis nor a theory

questions.neutral_comments: It is not possible to PROVE that a theory or hypothesis is correct. Instead the results of tests (experiments) may only show that a particular theory or hypothesis is false. For example, if your hypothesis for why a flashlight isn’t working is that the batteries are dead, you might predict that replacing the batteries will fix the flashlight. If you then test your prediction by replacing the batteries and find that the flashlight still does not work, you have disproven your original prediction that replacing the batteries would fix the flashlight and have thus shown your hypothesis to be incorrect (false). However, if the flashlight works after you replace the batteries, that finding does not prove that your prediction was correct and thus does not prove that your hypothesis was correct. This is because you can still come up with alternative hypotheses for why the flashlight now works. For example, you could hypothesize that the reason the flashlight wasn’t working previously was because the original batteries were inserted incorrectly. Then, when you replaced the batteries, you inserted them correctly and so fixed the flashlight. If that is the case, then your original hypothesis that the old batteries were dead would be false. The bottom line is that we can never rule out that there might be a different hypothesis that also explains all of the available experimental results and that is actually the correct hypothesis.

questions.question: Which of the following statements best distinguishes hypotheses from theories in science?

options.text: Hypotheses usually are relatively narrow in scope; theories have broad explanatory power.
Hypotheses are guesses; theories are correct answers.
Theories are proved true in all cases; hypotheses are usually falsified by tests.
Theories are hypotheses that have been proven.

questions.neutral_comments: Neither theories nor hypotheses can be proven correct beyond a shadow of a doubt. Although theories are supported by a large body of evidence, they sometimes need to be modified as new data become available. Theories are broader in scope than hypotheses.

questions.question: Experimentation is only one part of the process of scientific inquiry, but it is a very important step because it

options.text: gives the investigator a systematic, unbiased result
allows rejection of a hypothesis
ensures that the variable being tested is measured without error
ensures that hypotheses can be confirmed with certainty

questions.neutral_comments: Experiments are designed to test predictions. The prediction being tested is based on a hypothesis. Therefore, if the prediction is shown to be false, that result indicates that the hypothesis on which the prediction was based is also false. Carrying out experiments does not ensure that a hypothesis will be supported. Because hypotheses are only POSSIBLE answers to questions, many hypotheses turn out to be incorrect. In addition, it is not possible to prove that a hypothesis is correct as there will always be alternative explanations for why testing showed that a particular prediction was correct. Experiments don’t necessarily give investigators systematic unbiased results; it depends on how the experiments are designed and conducted. Similarly, it is difficult or impossible to ensure that variables being tested are measured without error.

questions.question: How many electrons do hydrogen atoms have in their valence shell?
The order of chemical bonds from strongest to weakest is

questions.neutral_comments: The carbon atom will form one covalent bond with each of the 4 hydrogen atoms. Each of the pairs of electrons forming these covalent bonds will be in one of the 4 orbitals that lie within the 2nd electron shell, and that point towards the 4 corners of a tetrahedron. This gives the molecule a roughly pyramidal shape.

questions.neutral_comments: Molecules are substances that consist of two or more atoms joined by covalent bonds. This definition applies to water, as water molecules consist of two hydrogen atoms, each joined to an oxygen atom by a covalent bond. Compounds are defined as substances consisting of two or more different elements combined in a fixed ratio. Water combines the elements hydrogen and oxygen in a fixed ratio, with two hydrogen atoms for every oxygen atom.

X will likely dissolve in the water, forming a solution where X is the solute and water is the solvent. Y will likely not dissolve in the water.

X will likely not dissolve in the water. Y will likely dissolve in the water, forming a solution where Y is the solvent and water is the solute.

questions.neutral_comments: “X” will likely dissolve in the water because hydrophilic (“water loving”) substances tend to dissolve in water whereas “Y” will likely not dissolve in water because hydrophobic (“water fearing) substances tend not to dissolve in water. A liquid solvent, such as water, dissolves solutes, such as “X”, to form solutions.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about moles is true?

options.text: One mole of hydrogen atoms weighs 1 g
One mole of hydrogen molecules (H2) weighs 2 g
All of these answers are correct.
A mole is 6.02 X 1023

questions.neutral_comments: All of these answers are correct. A mole is 6.02 X 1023. A hydrogen atom weighs one Dalton so one mole of hydrogen atoms weighs 1 g. One mole of hydrogen molecules (H2) weighs 2 g. This is because hydrogen molecules have the formula: H2. Therefore, the molecular weight of hydrogen molecules is 2 Daltons and a mole of hydrogen molecules will weigh 2 g.

questions.question: What is the pH of a solution with a hydroxyl ion [OH<sup>-</sup>] concentration of 10<sup>-4.5 </sup>M?

options.text: pH 2
pH 12
pH 9.5
pH 4.5

questions.neutral_comments: Remember that the concentration of hydroxyl ions times the concentration of hydrogen ions always equals 10-14 M (moles per liter) in aqueous solutions (at least around room temperature). So, if the hydroxyl ion concentration is 10-4.5 M, the hydrogen ion concentration must be 10-14/10-4.5= 10-9.5 M. The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration. The base 10 logarithm of 10-9.5 is -9.5, so the negative logarithm of 10-9.5is 9.5. Therefore, the pH of this solution is 9.5.

questions.question: A solution with a pH of 12 contains what concentration of hydroxyl ions [OH<sup>-</sup>]?

options.text: 2 moles/liter
0.01 moles/liter
10-12 moles/liter
0.12 moles/liter

questions.neutral_comments: The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration in moles per liter. In other words, pH = - log [H+]. So, in this case: 12 = - log [H+]. Or, -12 = log [H+]. Or, 10-12 M = [H+]. Furthermore, the concentration of hydroxyl ions times the concentration of hydrogen ions always equals 10-14 in aqueous solutions (at least around room temperature). So, if the hydrogen ion concentration is 10-12M (moles per liter), the hydroxyl ion concentration must be 10-14/10-12= 10-2 M, or 0.01 M, or 0.01 moles/liter.

questions.question: How many covalent bonds do nitrogen atoms need to form with other atoms to complete their valence shell?
questions.neutral_comments: Nitrogen atoms have 5 electrons in their valence shell, which is the 2ndelectron shell. The total number of electrons needed to fill the 2ndelectron shell is 8, so nitrogen needs to form 3 covalent bonds with other atoms so that it has 3 pairs of electrons that it is sharing via covalent bonds and one pair of electrons that it is not sharing, for a total of 4 pairs of electrons, or 8 total electrons.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about valence shells is FALSE?

options.text: Electrons in the valence shell (i.e. valence electrons) are primarily responsible for the chemical behavior of atoms.
The number of valence shells contained by a particular atom is dependent on how many electrons that atom has.
The valence shell is the highest energy electron shell an atom has.
The valence shell is the outermost electron shell of an atom.

questions.neutral_comments: Each atom has only one valence shell, corresponding to its outermost electron shell. Because the electrons in the valence shell are the outermost electrons and the energy level of an electron increases the further it is from the nucleus, the valence shell is the highest energy electron shell an atom has. Also, because atoms react to complete their valence shells, the valence electrons are primarily responsible for the chemical behavior of atoms.

The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration. The base 10 logarithm of 10-2 is -2, so the negative logarithm of 10-2 is 2. questions.question: What gives rise to the cohesiveness of water molecules?

options.text: Nonpolar covalent bonds
Hydrogen bonds
Ionic bonds
Hydrophobic interactions

questions.neutral_comments: Water molecules stick to each other because the oxygen atom in a water molecule carries a partial negative charge and the two hydrogen atoms each carry a partial positive charge. As a result, the partially positively charged hydrogen atoms of one water molecule are attracted to the partially negatively charged oxygen atoms of other water molecules. The reason that the hydrogen atoms carry partial positive charges and the oxygen atoms carry partial negative charges is that the covalent bonds within a water molecule are polar. Each electron pair forming a covalent bond between an oxygen atom and a hydrogen atom spends more time near oxygen than near hydrogen, as oxygen atoms are more electronegative than hydrogen atoms.

have an equal number of atoms
have about ten times as many molecules in the mole of glucose than in the mole of water
have an equal volume

questions.neutral_comments: A mole of water (H2O) molecules and a mole of glucose molecules (C6H12O6) will have an equal number of molecules (6.02 X 1023). Because there are more atoms in each glucose molecule than in each water molecule, a mole of glucose molecules will have more atoms than a mole of water molecules. A mole of water molecules and a mole of glucose molecules will not have an equal volume as 6.02 X 1023 molecules of glucose will not take up the same amount of space as 6.02 X 1023 molecules of water.

questions.question: Which of the following represents a polar bond?

options.text: C-H
C-O
options.comment: Yes! Oxygen is substantially more electronegative than carbon. As a result, the pair of electrons forming the covalent bond between oxygen and carbon will spend significantly more time closer to the oxygen atom than the carbon atom. This means the bond will be a polar covalent bond.

options.text: O=O

questions.question: When a sodium atom and a chlorine atom interact to complete their valence shells

options.text: an electron is transferred from sodium to chlorine, turning the sodium atom into a cation and the chlorine atom into an anion and allowing the two atoms to form an ionic bond
they form 1 polar covalent bond
they form 2 polar covalent bonds
an electron is transferred from sodium to chlorine, turning the sodium atom into an anion and the chlorine atom into a cation and allowing the two atoms to form an ionic bond

questions.neutral_comments: Chlorine is so much more electronegative than sodium that, rather than sharing a pair of electrons, the lone electron in the valence (= 3rd) shell of sodium is transferred to chlorine. That leaves the sodium cation with no electrons in the 3rd electron shell and a full set (8) of electrons in the 2nd electron shell. The 1 electron transferred to the chlorine atom is sufficient to complete the valence shell of that atom. Because chlorine now has one more electron than it has protons, the chlorine anion will have a charge of negative 1. Negatively charged ions are called “anions” and positively charged ions are called “cations”.

questions.question:
Why does the structure shown below fail to make sense chemically?

H-C=C-H

options.text: Each hydrogen atom only has 1 covalent bond.
Carbon is more electronegative than hydrogen and should thus remove electrons from hydrogen, rather than forming a covalent bond with hydrogen.
The two carbon atoms share more than 1 bond.
Each carbon atom only has 3 covalent bonds.

questions.neutral_comments: Carbon atoms need to form 4 covalent bonds, rather than just 3, to complete their valence shell. Carbon is only slightly more electronegative than hydrogen and so will not remove electrons from hydrogen. In addition, removing 4 electrons from hydrogen atoms to complete its valence shell would leave carbon with 4 more electrons than protons, which is energetically extremely unfavorable.

questions.neutral_comments: Compounds are substances consisting of two or more different elements combined in a fixed ratio. This criteria applies to all of the examples below, with the exception of H2 which consists only of atoms of a single element, hydrogen.

questions.question: The further on average an electron is from the nucleus

options.text: the greater its potential energy
the more highly charged it is
the less highly charged it is
the lower its potential energy

questions.neutral_comments: The further an electron is from the nucleus, the greater its potential energy. Think of it this way. Negatively charged electrons are attracted to the positively charged protons in the nucleus. So, it takes work to increase the separation between an electron and the nucleus. Some of the energy spent in doing this work is stored in the form of increasing the potential energy of the moved electron. This is conceptually similar to increasing the potential energy of a ball by carrying it higher up a hill.

questions.question: With regards to orbitals, which of the following statements is FALSE?

options.text: An orbital is occupied by one or two electrons.
An orbital can be depicted as a cloud where an electron may be located.
An orbital is a region surrounding the nucleus where the probability of finding an electron is high.
An orbital is a defined path that an electron follows as it orbits the nucleus.

questions.neutral_comments: Electrons do not follow defined paths and the position of an electron cannot be precisely known. Instead, we can only say that there is a high probability of a particular electron being located somewhere within a space defined by the orbital for that electron.

So, if the hydroxyl ion concentration is 10-4M (moles per liter), the hydrogen ion concentration must be 10-14/10-4= 10-10 M. The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration. The base 10 logarithm of 10-10 is -10, so the negative logarithm of 10-10is 10. Therefore, the pH of this solution is 10.

questions.question: The number of electron orbitals in the different electron shells is

options.text: 2 in the 1st shell and 4 in the second shell
1 in the 1st shell and 2 in the second shell
2 in the 1st shell and 8 in the second shell
1 in the 1st shell and 4 in the second shell

questions.neutral_comments: The first electron shell has one orbital and the second electron shell has four orbitals. Each orbital can contain a maximum of two electrons. Therefore the first electron shell can contain up to two electrons and the second electron shell can contain up to eight electrons.

questions.question: How many covalent bonds do carbon atoms need to form with other atoms to complete their valence shell?
questions.neutral_comments: Carbon atoms have 4 electrons in their valence shell, which is the 2ndelectron shell. The total number of electrons needed to fill the 2ndelectron shell is 8, so carbon needs to form 4 covalent bonds so that it is sharing a total of 8 electrons (2 electrons per covalent bond).

questions.question: The lowest energy mechanism by which a carbon atom may complete its valence shell is to

options.text: transfer the 4 electrons in its valence shell to other atoms or transfer 4 electrons from other atoms to its valence shell
transfer the 2 electrons in its valence shell to other atoms or transfer 2 electrons from other atoms to its valence shell
form 2 covalent bonds with other atoms
form 4 covalent bonds with other atoms

questions.neutral_comments: Forming only 2 covalent bonds with other atoms would not be sufficient for a carbon atom to complete its shell, as carbon atoms have 4 electrons in their valence shell (= the 2nd electron shell) and 8 electrons are needed to complete that shell. In theory the outermost shell could be completed by transferring 4 electrons from other atoms, but in practice this would leave the carbon atom with 4 more electrons than protons which is very unfavorable energetically. In theory the outermost shell could also be completed by transferring 4 electrons FROM carbon to other atoms, in which case the carbon atom would have no electrons in its 2nd shell and 2 electrons in its 1st shell, which would make the 1st shell its outermost, or valence, shell and that shell would be complete since it only takes 2 electrons to fill the 1st electron shell. However, this situation would leave the carbon atom with 4 less electrons than protons, which is a big difference in the number of electrons and protons and is extremely unstable in this case.

questions.question: Electrons exist only at fixed levels of potential energy. However, if an atom absorbs sufficient energy, a possible result is that

questions.neutral_comments: Water molecules are polar molecules as they carry partial positive and negative charges on different parts of the molecule. As a result, water molecules will tend to interact with other molecules that carry partial or full charges, including molecules with polar bonds, negatively charged molecules and atoms and positively charged molecules and anions.

questions.question: Water has a high specific heat because

pH 2

questions.question: How many electrons does it take to fill the first electron shell of a carbon atom?
questions.neutral_comments: The atoms of all elements need 2 electrons to complete their first electron shell.

questions.question: Depending on how far an electron is moved from the nucleus

options.text: you can decrease its potential energy by any amount
you can decrease its potential energy by only certain amounts
you can increase its potential energy by any amount
you can increase its potential energy by only certain amounts

questions.neutral_comments: The potential energy of electrons increases the further they are from the nucleus. However, electrons may only occupy certain defined orbitals that have certain defined average distances from the nucleus and thus certain energy levels. Think of it like a ball being moved up or down a set of steps. If a ball is moved up two steps its energy level will increase twice as much as if it is moved up one step (assuming the steps are of equal height). However, it is not feasible to increase the potential energy of the ball by 0.5 or 1.5 steps.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about electrons is FALSE?

options.text: two electrons may occupy the same electron orbital
electrons are negatively charged
the closer an electron is to the nucleus, the more strongly the electron is attracted to the nucleus and therefore the more potential energy the electron has
electrons are attracted to nuclei by the positive charges of the protons in the nuclei

questions.neutral_comments: It is true that the closer an electron is to the nucleus, the more strongly the electron is attracted to the nucleus. However, it is NOT true that an electron has more potential energy when it is closer to the nucleus. In fact, it will have less potential energy the closer it gets to the nucleus. Think of it this way, the further from the earth you send a rocket, the less strongly it is attracted to the earth by gravity, but the more potential energy it has.

questions.question: When atom “A” forms four single covalent bonds to complete its outermost electron shell, which is its 2<sup>nd</sup> electron shell, the electron orbitals within that shell will point towards the corners of

a tetrahedron

questions.question: If you make a model of a water molecule, the lines showing the relative positions of the covalent bonds will most closely resemble

options.text: a straight line
it depends on the water molecule
a “T”
a wide “V”

questions.neutral_comments: In a water molecule, each hydrogen atom is connected to the one oxygen atom by a covalent bond. The oxygen atom thus has a complete valence shell, with 2 pairs of electrons shared in covalent bonds and 2 unshared pairs of electrons. Since the 4 orbitals occupied by these 4 pairs of electrons point towards the 4 corners of a tetrahedron, the 2 pairs of electrons that form the 2 covalent bonds will point towards 2 of the corners of a tetrahedron and will thus form roughly a wide “V” shape.

questions.question: A solution with a pH of 10 contains what concentration of hydroxyl ions [OH<sup>-</sup>]?

Furthermore, the concentration of hydroxyl ions times the concentration of hydrogen ions always equals 10-14 in aqueous solutions (at least around room temperature). So, if the hydrogen ion concentration is 10-10M (moles per liter), the hydroxyl ion concentration must be 10-14/10-10= 10-4 M, or 0.0001 M, or 0.0001 moles/liter.

options.text: 0.001 moles/liter
0.15 moles/liter
1.5 moles/liter
0.03 moles/liter

questions.neutral_comments: The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration in moles per liter. In other words, pH = - log [H+]. So, in this case: 1.5 = - log [H+]. Or, -1.5 = log [H+]. Or, 10-1.5 = [H+]. Or, 0.03 moles/liter = [H+]. Note that you do NOT need to know the exact value of 10-1.5 to identify the correct answer for this question. If you realize that 10-1.5 is between 10-1(= 0.1) and 10-2 (= 0.01) in value, than you will see that the only answer that lies within this range is 0.03 moles/liter.

questions.question: How many electrons do carbon atoms have in their valence shell?
How many more electrons do nitrogen atoms need to complete their valence shell?
questions.neutral_comments: Nitrogen atoms have 7 electrons. 2 of those electrons fill the 1stelectron shell and the other 5 fill 5 of the 8 spots in the 2nd electron shell, which is outermost shell and thus the valence shell for nitrogen. Nitrogen thus needs 3 more electrons to fill its valence shell.

questions.question: What is the pH of a solution with a hydrogen ion [H<sup>+</sup>] concentration of 10<sup>-4 </sup>M?

options.text: pH 4
pH 2
pH 8
pH 10

questions.neutral_comments: The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration. In other words, pH = - log [H+]. The base 10 logarithm of 10-4 is -4, so the negative logarithm of 10-4is 4. Therefore, the pH of this solution is 4.

questions.question: You have a freshly prepared 1 M (molar) solution of glucose in water. You carefully pour out a 100 mL sample of that solution. How many glucose molecules are included in that 100 mL sample?
questions.neutral_comments: Remember that a mole is a number just like a “dozen” is a number. A “dozen” means “12”, and a “mole” means “6.02 X 1023”. A one molar solution has one mole of solute molecules per liter of solution, or 6.02 X 1023 molecules of solute per liter of solution. So, a 0.1 liters of a 1 molar solution will have 0.1 moles of solute molecules. 0.1 moles X (6.02 X 1023 molecules/mole) = 6.02 X 1022 molecules.

questions.question: A solution with a pH of 2 contains what concentration of hydrogen ions [H<sup>+</sup>]?

questions.neutral_comments: The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration in moles per liter. In other words, pH = - log [H+]. So, in this case: 2 = - log [H+]. Or, -2 = log [H+]. Or, 10-2 = [H+]. Or, 0.01 M = [H+].

questions.question: Which of the following statements is most broadly true of different elements?

options.text: The chemical behavior of atoms is mostly dependent on the electrons in their second electron shell.
The chemical behavior of atoms is mostly dependent on their valence electrons.
The chemical behavior of atoms is mostly dependent on the electrons in their first electron shell.
The chemical behavior of atoms is mostly dependent on the electrons in their third electron shell.

questions.neutral_comments: The chemical behavior of atoms is mostly dependent on their valence electrons, which are the electrons in their outermost, or valence, electron shell. Depending on the number of electrons the atoms of a particular element have, the electrons may be sufficient to fill only the 1st electron shell, leaving the 1st shell as the outermost shell. Atoms of elements with more electrons may have sufficient electrons to fill the first electron shell and to partially or fully fill the 2nd shell, but not to place any electrons in the 3rd electron shell. In that case, the 2ndshell would be the outermost shell that has electrons and would thus be the valence shell.

questions.question: How many molecules of glycerol (C3H8O3; molecular mass = 92) would be present in 1 L of a 1 M (molar) glycerol solution?
questions.neutral_comments: A one molar solution contains 1 mole of solute per liter of solution. So, 1 L of a 1 molar solution will contain 1 mole of solute. Remember that a mole is a number just like a “dozen” is a number. A “dozen” means “12”, and a “mole” means “6.02 X 1023”. So, 1 L of a 1 molar glycerol solution will have 1 mole, or 6.02 X 1023, glycerol molecules.

questions.question: Atoms with incomplete valence shells may complete their shell by

options.text: all three of the other answers are correct, depending on the atom in question
transferring electrons from another atom
sharing electrons with another atom
transferring electrons to another atom

questions.neutral_comments: Depending on the atom in question, the atom may complete its valence shell by sharing one or more pairs of electrons with one or more other atoms (thus forming one or more covalent bonds with those atoms) or by transferring one or more electrons to other atoms or by transferring one or more electrons from another atom.

questions.question: How many covalent bonds do hydrogen atoms need to form with other atoms to complete their valence shell?
questions.neutral_comments: Hydrogen atoms have 1 electron in their valence shell, which is the 1stelectron shell. The total number of electrons needed to fill the 1stelectron shell is 2, so hydrogen needs to form one covalent bond with another atom in order to fill its valence shell. Alternatively, hydrogen can “fill” its valence shell by transferring its one electron to another atom. You might expect that hydrogen could also fill its valence shell by transferring an electron FROM another atom, but that would leave the hydrogen with 2 electrons and only one proton which, it turns out, is energetically unfavorable.

questions.neutral_comments: Transferring four electrons to other atoms would leave the carbon atom with a charge of plus 4, which would make it quite unstable. Similarly, transferring four electrons from other atoms would leave the carbon atom with a charge of negative 4, which would also make it quite unstable. Instead, carbon atoms complete their valence shell by forming four covalent bonds.

questions.question: If two molecules have the same number of atoms of the same elements but different structures, the two molecules may be

options.text: Geometric isomers
Structural isomers
Enantiomers
All of these answers are correct

questions.neutral_comments: Isomers of any type (structural isomers, geometric isomers and enantiomers) all meet the criteria of having the same number of atoms of the same elements but different structures. Structural isomers have the further criteria that, for two molecules to be structural isomers of each other, they must differ in their covalent partnerships. In contrast, molecules that are geometric isomers or enantiomers do NOT differ in their covalent partnerships. Geometric isomers differ in the arrangement of atoms around a double bond. Enantiomers differ in the arrangement of atoms covalently bound to a central, asymmetric carbon and are mirror images of each other. Please see figure 4.7 in your textbook for a figure showing all three types of isomer.

questions.question: The two molecules shown in the figure below are best described as

options.text: Enantiomers
Isotopes
Structural isomers
Geometric isomers

questions.neutral_comments: These two molecules have the same formula (C4H10), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements (i.e. they each have 4 carbon atoms and 10 hydrogen atoms), but different 3-dimensional shapes. So, they are isomers of some sort. Because they differ in the covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are examples of the type of isomers known structural isomers.

questions.question: The molecules shown below are best described as

options.text: Isotopes
Structural isomers
Geometric isomers
Enantiomers

questions.neutral_comments: These two molecules have the same formula (CN2O2H4), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but different 3-dimensional shapes. So, they are isomers of some sort. Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers. In addition, because these molecules do not have 2 carbon atoms joined by a double bond, they cannot be geometric isomers. Instead, they are “enantiomers”. Enantiomers are mirror images of each other and cannot be superimposed on each other. This is quite similar to how our hands are mirror images of each other, but cannot be superimposed on each other. For example, imagine the palms of your hands as being carbon atom and the four fingers on each hand representing covalent bonds to 4 different groups. There is no way to place one hand on the other hand so that all four of your fingers will match up. Note that enantiomers only occur in molecules that have an asymmetric carbon. For a carbon to be asymmetric, it must form covalent bonds to 4 different groups.

questions.question: The molecules shown below are best described as

options.text: Structural isomers
Geometric isomers
Isotopes
Enantiomers

questions.neutral_comments: These two molecules have the same formula (C2O2H4), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but have different 3-dimensional shapes. So, they are isomers of some sort. Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers. For example, both carbon atoms in both molecules are attached to one hydroxyl (OH) group and one hydrogen atom. However, the two molecules do have different structures. Remember that double covalent bonds are inflexible. So, the above molecules cannot rotate around their double bonds in the way that they could if the two carbon atoms were only joined by single covalent bonds. So, in the molecule on the left, the two hydroxyl (OH) groups will always be on the opposite sides of the double bond, whereas the two hydroxyl groups will always be on the same side of the double bond in the molecule on the right. Molecules such as these two, which have the same covalent partnerships but different spatial arrangements, are known as geometric isomers. The molecule on the left, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the hydroxyl groups) on opposite sides of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a trans isomer. The molecule on the right, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the hydroxyl groups) on the same side of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a cis isomer.

options.text: It is the 3rd carbon from the left

questions.neutral_comments: Asymmetric carbons are carbons that are covalently bonded to 4 different groups. The 1st carbon on the left in this molecule is bonded to only 3 different groups (a hydrogen atom, an oxygen atom and a hydrocarbon chain). The 3rd carbon is also bonded to only 3 different groups (two hydrogen atoms, a short hydrocarbon chain and the part of the molecule that is to the left of that carbon atom). The 4th carbon from the left is only bound to 3 different groups (2 hydrogen atoms, a methyl group and the rest of the molecule that is to the left of the 4th carbon). The 5th (last) carbon from the left is only bonded to 2 different groups as it forms covalent bonds with 3 hydrogen atoms and the rest of the molecule that is to the left of the 5th carbon. In contrast, the 2nd carbon from the left is bound to 4 different groups: a COH group, a hydrogen atom, an OH group and a short hydrocarbon chain. Each of the four different groups to which the second carbon from the left is bound is shown circled in red in the figure below.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is FALSE?

options.text: Nucleotides are the monomers from which nucleic acids are formed.
Fatty acids are the monomers from which lipid molecules are formed.
Amino acids are the monomers from which proteins are formed.
Sugars are the monomers from which polysaccharides are formed.

questions.neutral_comments: Fatty acids are important in lipid formation, but are not monomers as monomers are simple molecules, many of which are combined to form a polymer. In contrast, fatty acids are fairly large molecules and few of them are used to make a lipid molecule. For example, just two fatty acid molecules are used in the synthesis of a typical membrane lipid molecule (e.g. a phospholipid) and just three fatty acid molecules are used to make a typical lipid molecule in fat (e.g. a triacylglycerol molecule). In addition, monomers are linked together like cars forming a train to form a polymer. In contrast, the fatty acid molecules that are used to form lipids are not joined to each other. For example, the three fatty acid molecules used to form a triacylglycerol molecule (a type of lipid molecule) are each joined separately to different parts of a glycerol molecule. So, remember that lipids are the one type of biological macromolecule we will discuss that are NOT polymers because they are NOT composed of monomers.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the nucleotides used in RNA synthesis is correct?

The nucleotides used in RNA synthesis have deoxyribose as their sugar component and do not include nucleotides that have uracil as their nitrogenous base.
The nucleotides used in RNA synthesis have deoxyribose as their sugar component and do not include nucleotides that have thymine as their nitrogenous base.
The nucleotides used in RNA synthesis have ribose as their sugar component and do not include nucleotides that have uracil as their nitrogenous base.

In other words, they bind so that the 5’ end of one strand is hydrogen bonded to the 3’ end of the other strand. Also, remember that U (for RNA) or T (for DNA) hydrogen bonds with A, and G hydrogen bonds with C. So, you have: DNA 5’ TCTGAA 3’RNA 3’ AGACUU 5’ If you then follow the convention of writing nucleic acid molecules down starting at their 5’ end, the sequence for the RNA molecule is: 5’ UUCAGA 3’

questions.question: If you were asked to build a polymer that is two monomers long (ok, that wouldn’t really be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and you could use two different types of monomers, “A” and “B”, how many different polymers could you build?
questions.neutral_comments: You could build 4 different polymers: A-A, B-B, A-B and B-A. You might wonder if A-B and B-A are really the same thing. They are not the same thing because one end of a polymer has a hydrogen attached and the other end of the polymer has a hydroxyl group. In other words, you could write the above molecules as: H-O-A-B-H and H-O-B-A-H, which makes it clear that they are not the same molecule.

questions.question: What is a triacylglycerol?

A protein with a tertiary structure

questions.neutral_comments: Tricacylglycerols are lipids made with three fatty acids and glycerol. They are generally used in fat storage, rather than to make membranes.

questions.question: Which of the following are NOT polymers:

questions.neutral_comments: Lipids are large biological molecules. However they are not polymers because they are not composed of repeating units of simple monomers. In contrast, polysaccharides are polymers composed of repeating monomers (= monosaccharides), polypeptides (proteins) are polymers composed of repeating monomers (= amino acids) and nucleic acids are polymers composed of monomers (nucleotides).

questions.question: L-methionine and D-methionine are examples of

options.text: geometric isomers
enantiomers
all of these answers are correct
structural isomers

questions.neutral_comments: All amino acids except glycine have an asymmetric carbon, meaning a carbon atom that is covalently bound to 4 different groups. In the case of all amino acids except glycine, those groups are: a carboxyl group, an amino group, a hydrogen and an "R" group. The reason that glycine does not have an asymmetric carbon is because the R group of glycine is hydrogen. So, the central carbon of a glycine molecule is only bound to 3 different groups, since it is bound to two hydrogen atoms. Molecules with asymmetric carbons may occur as two different isomers, known as enantiomers. Enantiomers have the same covalent partnerships (i.e. they do NOT differ in which elements are covalently bound to which other elements), but are instead mirror images of each other. L-methionine and D-methionine meet this definition and so are enantiomers. Please see figure 4.7 in your book for a figure illustrating the different types of isomers.

Similarly, phospholipids contain two fatty acid molecules, a glycerol molecule and a head group. The fatty acids used in synthesis of phospholipids may or may not contain C=C double bonds.

questions.question: Glucose and fructose are examples of

options.text: geometric isomers
all of these answers are correct
stereoisomers
structural isomers

questions.neutral_comments: Glucose and fructose have the same molecular formula (C6H12O6), but different shapes, so you can see that they are isomers of some sort. To determine what type of isomers they represent, first look to see if the two molecules (glucose and fructose), share the same covalent partnerships. If you look at them, you will see that they do not share the same covalent partnerships. For example, the position of the carbon:oxygen double bond (C=O) is different for glucose and fructose. This means that glucose and fructose are examples of structural isomers. The other two types of isomers we studied, geometric isomers and enantiomers, do NOT differ in their covalent partnerships.

questions.question: If you were asked to build a polymer that is 30 monomers long, and you could use two different types of monomers, “A” and “B”, how many different polymers could you build?

options.text: ~ 1 billion

questions.neutral_comments: Think of it this way: If you were asked to build a polymer that was just one monomer long (ok, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), you would be able to build just two different “polymers”: A and B. If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 2 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), you would be able to build just 4 different “polymers”: AA, AB, BA and BB. If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 3 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), you would be able to build just 8 different “polymers”: AAA, AAB, ABA, BAA, ABB, BAB. BBA and BBB. Are you seeing a pattern here? The answer to this type of question may be found using the following formula: Number of different polymers that may be formed = XY, where “X” is the number of different types of monomers available and “Y” is the number of monomers in the polymer. So, if you were asked to build a polymer that is 30 monomers long, and you could use two different types of monomers, “A” and “B”, the number of different polymers you could build would be: 230 = ~ 1,000,000,000

Also, remember that U (for RNA) or T (for DNA) hydrogen bonds with A, and G hydrogen bonds with C. So, you have: DNA 5’ GAGGCTT 3’RNA 3’ CUCCGAA 5’ If you then follow the convention of writing nucleic acid molecules down starting at their 5’ end, the sequence for the RNA molecule is: 5’ AAGCCUC 3’

options.text: ~ 1 million

questions.neutral_comments: Think of it this way: If you were asked to build a polymer that was just one monomer long (ok, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and you had only “A” and “B” monomers available to use, you would be able to build just two different “polymers”: A and B. If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 2 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and had only “A” and “B” monomers available, you would be able to build just 4 different “polymers”: AA, AB, BA and BB. If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 3 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and had only “A” and “B” monomers available, you would be able to build just 8 different “polymers”: AAA, AAB, ABA, BAA, ABB, BAB. BBA and BBB. Are you seeing a pattern here? The answer to this type of question may be found using the following formula: Number of different polymers that may be formed = XY, where “X” is the number of different types of monomers available and “Y” is the number of monomers in the polymer. So, if you were asked to build a polymer that is 20 monomers long, and you could use four different types of monomers, the number of different polymers you could build would be: 420 = ~ 1 x 1012

questions.question: How many water molecules are needed to completely hydrolyze a polymer that is 18 nucleotides long?
questions.neutral_comments: Think of it this way: How many water molecules would be needed to completely hydrolyze a “polymer” that is just two nucleotides long? You would need just one, to split the one bond joining the two monomers, right? So, how many water molecules would you need to completely hydrolyze a “polymer” that is 3 monomers long? The answer is that you would need 2 water molecules, one to split the bond between the 1stand 2nd monomers and the other to hydrolyze the bond between the 2ndand 3rd monomers. So, you to completely hydrolyze a polymer takes one less water molecule than the number of monomers in the polymer.

questions.question: A dehydration reaction joins two glucose molecules to form maltose. The formula for glucose is C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>12</sub>O<sub>6</sub>. What is the correct formula for maltose?
questions.neutral_comments: You are joining two molecules of glucose to form maltose, so maltose will have twice as many atoms of each element as glucose, except that you have to remember that a water molecule is lost during the dehydration reaction. So, maltose will have 12 carbon atoms, but only 22 hydrogen atoms instead of 24 because of the two hydrogen atoms lost during formation of the water molecule. Similarly, maltose will have 11 oxygen atoms instead of 12, as one oxygen atom is used to form the water molecule.

questions.question: If starch and cellulose are both polymers of glucose, how come people can digest starch but not cellulose?

When glucose monomers are joined by dehydration reactions to form cellulose, the glucose monomers are converted into xylose molecules that are impossible for us to digest.
When glucose monomers are joined by dehydration reactions to form cellulose, the glucose monomers are converted into non-sugar molecules that are impossible for us to digest.
When glucose monomers are joined by dehydration reactions to form cellulose, the glucose monomers are converted into lactose molecules, which are hard for many people to digest.

The phospholipids are arranged in a bilayer, with their hydrocarbon tails pointing toward the interior of the membrane and their phosphate groups on the outside of the bilayer.
The phospholipids are arranged in a monolayer, with their hydrocarbon tails on the outside of the cell and their phosphate groups pointing toward the interior of the cell.

questions.question: Cell membranes are asymmetrical. Which of the following is most likely to explain part of the reason for this asymmetry?

options.text: Cell membranes communicate signals from one cell to another.
Proteins can only span membranes if they are hydrophobic.
Cell membrane proteins are inserted into the rough ER membrane with a certain orientation as they are being synthesized.
The cell membrane forms a border between different cell types.

questions.neutral_comments: Integral membrane proteins are inserted into the membrane of the rough endoplasmic reticulum (ER) as they are being synthesized by ribosomes bound to the rough ER. Because many of these proteins have both hydrophobic regions, which are embedded in the membrane, and hydrophilic regions, which are exposed to the aqueous environment inside or outside of the ER, they are not able to move randomly from one side of the membrane to the other after they are made. For example, if a membrane protein is synthesized such that the last part of the protein that is made is hydrophilic and is exposed on the outside of the ER membrane, that part of that protein will remain on the outside of the ER membrane and then on the outside of the vesicle that transports it to the Golgi, on the outside of the Golgi, on the outside of the vesicle that transports it the plasma membrane and then on the inside (cytoplasmic side) of the plasma membrane. It should be noted that the lipid compositions of the two halves of a lipid bilayer are not identical either, as lipid molecules very rarely flip-flop from one side of the bilayer to the other and different species of lipid molecules are synthesized in different amounts in the two halves of the bilayer.

a bouncer at a club who only admits appropriately dressed people

questions.question: Which of the following would require an energy expenditure?

moving Na+ outside of the cell if the extracellular fluid has higher concentrations of Na+ and protons than the intracellular fluid
all of these answers are correct
moving Na+ out of the cell if the extracellular fluid already has a higher Na+ concentration, but the proton concentration is equal inside and outside of the cell

questions.neutral_comments: Moving an ion up its electrochemical gradient requires an energy expenditure. In each of the answers below, Na+ is moving up its electrochemical gradient.

questions.question: A patient had a serious accident and lost a lot of blood. In an attempt to replenish body fluids, distilled water, equal to the volume of blood lost, is transferred directly into one of his veins. What will be the most probable result of this transfusion?

options.text: The patient’s red blood cells will shrink because the blood fluid is hypotonic compared to the red blood cells.
The patient’s red blood cells will shrink because the blood fluid is hypertonic compared to the red blood cells.
The patient’s red blood cells will swell, and possibly burst, because the blood fluid is hypotonic compared to the red blood cells.
The patient’s red blood cells will swell, and possibly burst, because the blood fluid is hypertonic compared to the red blood cells.

questions.neutral_comments: Pure water, which by definition contains no solutes, will be hypotonic compared to the solution inside of the patient’s red blood cells, which contain lots of solutes. That means that adding pure water to the patient’s blood stream will cause there to be more water molecules interacting with solute molecules inside of the red blood cells than outside. That in turn means that there will be fewer free water molecules inside of the patient’s red blood cells than outside of them. Water will thus flow into the red blood cells, causing the cells to swell and possibly burst.

questions.question: What are the membrane structures that function in active transport?

options.text: peripheral proteins
cholesterol
glycolipids
integral proteins

questions.neutral_comments: Active transport is carried out by proteins. To transport a molecule across a membrane, the protein will need to be in the membrane and will therefore need to be an integral membrane protein.

questions.question: The sodium-potassium pump in animal cells requires cytoplasmic ATP to pump ions across the plasma membrane. When the proteins of the pump are first synthesized in the rough ER, what side of the ER membrane will the ATP binding site be on?

options.text: It could be on either side because the orientation of proteins is scrambled in the Golgi apparatus.
It will be inside the membrane and will become exposed once it reaches the plasma membrane.
It will be on the side facing the interior of the ER (i.e. the lumenal side).
It will be on the cytoplasmic side of the ER.

questions.neutral_comments: Protein domains that are on the cytoplasmic side of the ER will end up on the cytoplasmic side of the vesicles that bud off of the ER, than on the cytoplasmic side of the Golgi, then on the cytoplasmic side of the vesicles that bud off of the Golgi apparatus and then on the cytoplasmic side of the plasma membrane after the vesicle fuses with the plasma membrane (see figure below, paying special attention to the orientation of the small, green carbohydrates that are attached to the protein molecules in the rough ER).

questions.question: As material diffuses across a membrane from the side of higher concentration to the side of lower concentration,

options.text: osmotic pressure will not develop unless the membrane is equally permeable to the solvent and all the solutes.
ATP is required for this diffusion.
the free energy of the system decreases.
the free energy of the system increases.

questions.question: Sucrose-H<sup>+</sup> cotransporters transport sucrose and H<sup>+</sup> from outside to inside of a cell. Which of the following would increase the rate of sucrose transport into the cell?

options.text: adding a substance that makes the membrane more permeable to H+
decreasing the concentration of sucrose outside of the cell
increasing the pH of the solution outside of the cell
decreasing the pH of the solution outside of the cell

questions.neutral_comments: Decreasing the pH of the solution outside of the cell would increase the concentration of H+ outside of the cell. Therefore decreasing the pH outside of the cell would increase the H+ gradient from the outside to the inside of the cell and would thus increase the rate at which H+and sucrose are transported into the cell.

questions.question: Which of the following shows the correct pathway for synthesis of plasma membrane proteins?

options.text: Smooth ER to vesicle to Golgi to vesicle to plasma membrane
Rough ER to vesicle to Golgi to vesicle to plasma membrane
Smooth ER to rough ER to vesicle to Golgi to vesicle to plasma membrane
Golgi to vesicle to rough ER to vesicle to plasma membrane

questions.neutral_comments: Plasma membrane proteins are synthesized at the rough ER, which is called the “rough” ER because of all the ribosomes stuck to it. Smooth ER is not involved in the synthesis of plasma membrane proteins. After being synthesized in the rough ER and possibly having carbohydrates added, plasma membrane proteins are transported via vesicles to the Golgi apparatus where they are modified and then transported via vesicles to the plasma membrane.

questions.question: Use the diagram below to help answer this question. The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a selectively permeable barrier. This selectively permeable barrier is permeable to water but not to any ions. If you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of MgCl2 to side “A” and you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of NaCl to side “B”, at equilibrium

options.text: there will have been a net flow of water from side “B” to side “A”
there will have been no net flow of water between the two sides of the tube
there will have been a net flow of water from side “A” to side “B”
there will have been no movement of water molecules across the membrane

questions.neutral_comments: MgCl2 and NaCl are both salts that will dissociate into their constituent ions when they come in contact with water. So, the 1 mole of MgCl2 will dissociate to form 1 mole of Mg++ and 2 moles of Cl- and the 1 mole of NaCl will dissociate to form 1 mole of Na+and 1 mole of Cl-. That means that, immediately after the solutions are added to the two sides of the tube, there will be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B. As a result, more water molecules will be interacting with solute molecules on side A and there will therefore be a lower concentration of free water molecules on side A than on side B. That, in turn, means there will be a net flow of water molecules from side B to side A, until equilibrium is reached.

questions.question: Which of the following is a reasonable explanation for why unsaturated lipids help keep membranes more fluid at lower temperatures?

options.text: The double bonds result in shorter hydrocarbon chains and thinner membranes.
Unsaturated lipids have a higher cholesterol content and therefore more cholesterol in the membranes.
