The double bonds form kinks in the hydrocarbon chains, forcing adjacent lipid molecules to be further apart.
Unsaturated lipids permit more water in the interior of the membrane.

questions.question: Which of the following membrane activities requires a direct input of energy from ATP hydrolysis?

options.text: facilitated diffusion
Nat+ ions moving out of the cell, up their concentration gradient
movement of water into a cell
movement of glucose molecules

questions.question: When a plant cell is submerged in a very hypotonic solution, what is likely to occur?

options.text: the cell membrane will lyse
the cell will burst
the cell will become turgid (solid, due to being inflated)
the cell will become limp

questions.neutral_comments: Hypotonic solutions have a lower concentration of solutes. As a result, hypotonic solutions have fewer water molecules interacting with solute molecules and therefore have more free water molecules. Free water molecules will thus diffuse into the plant cell, causing it to expand against the cell wall, making it more solid, or turgid.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding integral membrane proteins is TRUE?

options.text: They are not mobile within the bilayer.
They are loosely bound to the surface of the bilayer.
They are usually transmembrane proteins.
They serve only a structural role in membranes.

questions.question: Which of the following types of molecules are the major structural components of the cell membrane?

options.text: Phospholipids and proteins
Triacylglycerols and carbohydrates
Triacylglycerols and proteins
Phospholipids and carbohydrates

questions.neutral_comments: The major structural components of cell membranes are phospholipids and proteins. Carbohydrates are present in membranes (attached to proteins, to form glycoproteins, or attached to lipids, to form glycolipids), but represent only a small part of the components of a membrane. Triacylglycerols are fats and are rare in membranes.

questions.question: Proteins that have carbohydrates attached to them are known as

options.text: sugar-proteins
carboproteins
saccharoproteins
glycoproteins

questions.question: Use the diagram below to help answer this question. The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a selectively permeable barrier. This selectively permeable barrier is permeable to water but not to any ions. If you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of MgCl2 to side “A” and you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of NaCl to side “B”, immediately after adding the solutions to the U-tube,

options.text: there will be more free water molecules on side “A”
the solution in side “A” will be isotonic compared with the solution in side “B”
the solution in side “A” will be hypotonic compared with the solution in side “B”
the solution in side “A” will be hypertonic compared with the solution in side “B”

questions.neutral_comments: MgCl2 and NaCl are both salts that will dissociate into their constituent ions when they come in contact with water. So, the 1 mole of MgCl2 will dissociate to form 1 mole of Mg++ and 2 moles of Cl- and the 1 mole of NaCl will dissociate to form 1 mole of Na+and 1 mole of Cl-. That means that, immediately after the solutions are added to the two sides of the tube, there will be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B, so side A will be hypertonic compared with side B. The fact that there will be more solute molecules on side A also means that more of the water molecules on side A will be interacting with solute molecules and therefore there will be fewer free water molecules on side A.

questions.question: Osmosis refers to

options.text: the diffusion of water across a selectively permeable barrier
all of these answers are correct
the diffusion of ions across a selectively permeable barrier
the diffusion of solutes across a selectively permeable barrier

questions.question: According to the fluid mosaic model of membrane structure, proteins of the membrane are mostly

options.text: confined to the hydrophobic core of the membrane
spread in a continuous layer over the inner and outer surfaces of the membranes
randomly oriented in the membrane, with no fixed inside-outside polarity
embedded in the lipid bilayer

questions.question: Why are lipids and some proteins free to move laterally in membranes?

options.text: The interior of the membrane is filled with liquid water.
The hydrophilic portions of the lipids are in the interior of the membrane.
Molecules such as cellulose can pull them in various directions.
There are only weak hydrophobic interactions in the interior of the membrane.

questions.question: When a hydrogen ion (= a proton) enters a cell, it is

options.text: moving down its electrochemical gradient because the outsides of cells are positively charged relative to the insides and that offsets the fact that the hydrogen ion concentration inside of cells is greater than outside of cells

moving down its electrochemical gradient as the hydrogen ion concentration is so much greater outside of cells than inside that this effect offsets the effect of the outsides of cells being negatively charged relative to the insides
moving down its electrochemical gradient as the hydrogen ion concentration is greater outside of cells and the outsides of cells are positively charged relative to the insides
moving up its electrochemical gradient as the hydrogen ion concentration is lower outside of cells and the outsides of cells are negatively charged relative to the insides

questions.question: The two layers of a lipid bilayer

options.text: none of these answers are correct
have almost identical lipid compositions as lipid molecules can move freely between the two layers
have both similar lipid and integral membrane protein compositions
are similar in terms of the types and numbers of their integral membrane proteins as proteins can move freely between the two layers

questions.neutral_comments: The two layers of a lipid bilayer have different lipid and different protein compositions. Remember that although lipid molecules can diffuse laterally within 1 face of a membrane, it is very rare for a lipid molecule to flip-flop from on ½ (face) of a membrane to the other because for that to happen the hydrophilic part of the lipid molecule (e.g. the phosphate and groups attached to the phosphate of a phospholipid molecule) would need to pass through the hydrophobic core of the membrane. Similarly, protein molecules may not be able to move between the two layers of a lipid bilayer.

questions.question: Which of the following types of molecules are the major structural components of the cell membrane?

options.text: proteins and cellulose
phospholipids and proteins
glycoproteins and triglycerides
phospholipids and cellulose

questions.neutral_comments: The major structural components of cell membranes are phospholipids and proteins. Triglycerides are important in fats, but aren't important in cell membranes. Cellulose forms most of the cell wall of plant cells but is not part of cell membranes.

questions.question: Which of the following is one of the ways that the membranes of winter wheat are able to remain fluid when it is extremely cold?

options.text: by using active transport
by increasing the percentage of unsaturated phospholipids in the membrane
by increasing the percentage of cholesterol molecules in the membrane
by decreasing the number of hydrophobic proteins in the membrane

questions.neutral_comments: Increasing the percentage of unsaturated phospholipids make membranes more fluid, even at lower temperatures, by inhibiting close packing of the fatty acid chains of the molecules, thus disrupting hydrophobic interactions between the molecules. Cholesterol does lower the freezing temperatures of membranes in animal cells, but is not found in plant cells. The percentage of hydrophobic proteins in the membrane has little or no effect on the temperature at which the membrane will freeze.

questions.question: Channel proteins

options.text: form tracks within a cell that help direct movement of vesicles
form “corridors” that allow specific ions or molecules to cross membranes
channel small ions to specific subcellular compartments
form ”corridors” that allow any small molecule to cross membranes

questions.neutral_comments: Channel proteins form channels that allow specific ions or molecules to cross membranes.

questions.question: Lipid molecules that have carbohydrates attached to them are known as

options.text: glycolipids
polysaccharolipids
carbolipids
saccharolipids

questions.question: Use the diagram below to help answer this question. The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a semi-permeable barrier. This semi-permeable barrier is permeable to water and glucose, but not to sucrose. If you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 2 moles of sucrose and 1 mole of glucose to side “A” of the tube, and 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of sucrose and 2 moles of glucose to side “B” of the tube, after the system reaches equilibrium, what changes are observed?

options.text: The concentration of glucose on side A is less than 1 M and the concentration of sucrose on side A is 2 M.
The concentration of glucose on side A is less than 1 M and the concentration of sucrose on side A is less than 2 M.
The concentration of glucose on side A is 1.5 M and the concentration of sucrose on side A is less than 2 M.
The concentration of glucose on side A is 1.5 M and the concentration of sucrose on side A is 2 M.

questions.neutral_comments: Because the membrane is permeable to glucose, right after the solutions are added to the U-tube the rate at which glucose molecules move from side B to side A will be higher than the rate at which glucose molecules move from side A to side B. This will continue until the system reaches equilibrium, at which point there will be an equal concentration of glucose molecules on both sides of the tube. As the system started out with 1 l of a 1 M glucose solution and 1 l of a 2 M glucose solution, at equilibrium there will be 2 l of a 1.5 M glucose solution. So, the glucose concentration on both sides of the U-tube at equilibrium will be 1.5 M. Because the membrane is not permeable to sucrose, the net movement of glucose molecules from side B to side A before equilibrium is reached will cause there to be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B. That means there will be a lower concentration of free water molecules on side A than on side B, which in turn means that there will be a net flow of water molecules from side B to side A until equilibrium is reached. At that point, there will be more than 1 l of solution on side A and therefore the sucrose concentration will have dropped to less than 2 M on side A.

questions.question: Which of the following will decrease the temperature at which the membranes of your cells will solidify?

options.text: adding more fatty acids with double bonds to the phospholipids composing your membranes
adding more unsaturated fatty acids to the phospholipids composing your membranes
adding cholesterol to the membranes
all of these answers are correct

questions.neutral_comments: Both cholesterol, as well as unsaturated lipids (= lipids with carbon-carbon double bonds), decrease the temperature at which membranes will solidify.

questions.question: In what way do the membranes of eukaryotic cells vary?

options.text: Only certain membranes of the cell are selectively permeable
Certain proteins are unique to each membrane.
Phospholipids are found in only certain membranes.
Only certain membranes are constructed of amphipathic molecules

questions.neutral_comments: All membranes are selectively permeable (although they may differ in the nature of the molecules to which they are permeable) and are composed of phospholipids, which are amphipathic molecules (= molecules having both hydrophobic and hydrophilic regions). The primary way in which membranes differ is in their protein compositions.

questions.question: Which of these often serve as cell recognition molecules on cell surfaces?

options.text: integral proteins
glycoproteins
transmembrane proteins
peripheral proteins

questions.neutral_comments: Glycoproteins (proteins with carbohydrates attached to them) and glycolipids (lipids with carbohydrates attached to them) play an important role in cell-cell recognition. For example, A, B, AB and O blood types reflect variations in the carbohydrates present on the surface of red blood cells.

questions.question: Which of the following span the phospholipid bilayer, usually a number of times?

options.text: peripheral proteins
integrins
transmembrane proteins
integral proteins

questions.question: Use the diagram below to help answer this question. The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a selectively permeable barrier. This selectively permeable barrier is permeable to water, but not to glucose. If you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of glucose to side “A” and you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of glucose to side “B”,

options.text: there will be no net flow of water between the two sides of the tube
there will be a net flow of water from side “B” to side “A”
there will be a net flow of water from side “A” to side “B”
there will be no movement of water molecules across the membrane

questions.neutral_comments: In this case, the concentration of glucose is the same on both sides of the tube. So, the concentration of free water molecules is the same on both sides of the tube. Free water molecules will still cross the membrane, but the rate at which free water molecules cross from side A to side B will be equal to the rate at which free water molecules cross from side B to side A. So, free water molecules WILL still cross the membrane, but there will be not NET flow of water between the two sides of the tube.

questions.question: What kinds of molecules can pass through a cell membrane most easily?

options.text: large and hydrophobic
small and hydrophilic
small and hydrophobic
large and hydrophilic

questions.neutral_comments: Small molecules can most easily fit between the molecules that form membranes. Hydrophobic (= water fearing) molecules can interact more easily with lipid molecules, which are also very hydrophobic.

questions.question: The sucrose-H<sup>+</sup> cotransporter is able to transport sucrose molecules up their concentration gradient, into cells, because

options.text: ATP induces conformational changes in the sucrose-H+ cotransporter protein
transporting a negatively charged sucrose molecule is offset by simultaneously transporting a positively charged H+
all of these answers are correct
of the energy gained by simultaneously transporting an H+ down its electrochemical gradient

questions.question: In order for a protein to be a transmembrane protein it would have to be which of the following?

options.text: hydrophobic
amphipathic
a glycoprotein
hydrophilic

questions.neutral_comments: Transmembrane proteins go all the way across membranes. They need to have hydrophobic (water fearing) segments that can be inserted inside the membrane and hydrophilic sections that are exposed to the aqueous solution on either side of the membrane. They are thus amphipathic molecules, meaning molecules with both hydrophobic and hydrophilic parts.

questions.question: In the term “fluid mosaic model”

options.text: “fluid” means the membrane is fluid and “mosaic” means that it contains a mixture of different types of lipid molecules
“fluid” means the membrane is fluid and “mosaic” means the membrane has different proteins embedded in it or attached to it
all of these answers are correct
“fluid” means that different proteins can float into and out of the membrane and “mosaic” means that the membrane contains a mixture of different types of lipid molecules

questions.question: Which of the following membrane activities require energy from ATP hydrolysis?

options.text: facilitated diffusion
movement of solutes by channel proteins
proton pumps
movement of solutes by co-transporters

questions.question: Carbohydrates attached to some proteins and lipids of the plasma membrane are added as the membrane is made and refined in the ER and Golgi apparatus: the new membrane then forms transport vesicles that travel to the cell surface. Which of the following statements is TRUE?

options.text: The carbohydrates that are part of the glycolipid and glycoprotein molecules will be on the inside of the vesicle and the inside (cytoplasmic side) of the plasma membrane.
The carbohydrates that are part of the glycolipid and glycoprotein molecules will be on the outside of the vesicle and then on the inside (cytoplasmic side) of the plasma membrane.
The carbohydrates that are part of the glycolipid and glycoprotein molecules will be on the outside of the vesicle and then on the outside (extracellular side) of the plasma membrane.
The carbohydrates that are part of the glycolipid and glycoprotein molecules will be on the inside of the vesicle and then on the outside (extracellular side) of the plasma membrane.

questions.neutral_comments: Carbohydrates that are attached to lipids or proteins on the inside face of the ER membrane will end up on the inside face of the membrane of vesicles that bud off of the ER, than on the inside face of the Golgi apparatus membrane, then on the inside face of the membrane of vesicles that bud off of the Golgi apparatus and then on the extracellular face of the plasma membrane after the vesicle fuses with the plasma membrane (see figure below, paying special attention to the orientation of the small, green carbohydrates that are attached to the protein molecules in the rough ER to help you keep track of the orientation of membrane components). Also, remember that lipid molecules can diffuse laterally within 1 face of a membrane, but that it is very rare for a lipid molecule to flip-flop from on ½ (face) of a membrane to the other because for that to happen the hydrophilic part of the lipid molecule (e.g. the phosphate and groups attached to the phosphate of a phospholipid molecule) would need to pass through the hydrophobic core of the membrane.

questions.question: Use the diagram below to help answer this question. The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a selectively permeable barrier. This selectively permeable barrier is permeable to water but not to glucose. If you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 2 moles of glucose to side “A” and you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of glucose to side “B”, what will have happened in order for the system to reach equilibrium?

options.text: there will have been no net flow of water between the two sides of the tube
there will have been a net flow of water from side “B” to side “A”
there will have been no movement of water molecules across the membrane
there will have been a net flow of water from side “A” to side “B”

questions.neutral_comments: Initially there will be a higher concentration of glucose molecules on side A than on side B, meaning that more water molecules will be interacting with glucose molecules on side A and there will therefore be a lower concentration of free water molecules on side A than on side B. As a result, there will be a net flow of water molecules from side B to side A, until equilibrium is established.

questions.question: Of the following functions, which is most important for the glycoproteins and glycolipids in animal cell membranes?

options.text: Helping cells distinguish one type of neighboring cell from another.
Maintaining membrane fluidity at low temperatures.
Facilitated diffusion of molecules down their concentrations gradients.
Active transport of molecules against their concentration gradients.

questions.neutral_comments: Glycoproteins (proteins with carbohydrates attached to them) and glycolipids (lipids with carbohydrates attached to them) play an important role in cell-cell recognition. For example, A, B, AB and O blood types reflect variations in the carbohydrates present on the surface of red blood cells.

questions.question: A lipid molecule that starts on the inside face of the ER membrane (i.e. the side of the ER membrane that is NOT in contact with the cytosol) and is then transported to the plasma membrane will

options.text: be evenly distributed between the inside and outside faces of the plasma membrane
most likely end up on the outside (extracellular) face of the plasma membrane
most likely end up on the inside (cytosolic) face of the plasma membrane
it is impossible to tell without knowing more about the lipid molecule

questions.neutral_comments: Lipids that are on the inside face of the ER membrane will end up on the inside face of the membrane of vesicles that bud off of the ER, than on the inside face of the Golgi apparatus membrane, then on the inside face of the membrane of vesicles that bud off of the Golgi apparatus and then on the extracellular face of the plasma membrane after the vesicle fuses with the plasma membrane (see figure below, paying special attention to the orientation of the small, green carbohydrates that are attached to the protein molecules in the rough ER to help you keep track of the orientation of membrane components). Also, remember that lipid molecules can diffuse laterally within 1 face of a membrane, but that it is very rare for a lipid molecule to flip-flop from on ½ (face) of a membrane to the other because for that to happen the hydrophilic part of the lipid molecule (e.g. the phosphate and groups attached to the phosphate of a phospholipid molecule) would need to pass through the hydrophobic core of the membrane.

questions.question: Ions always diffuse across membranes down their

options.text: electrochemical gradients
concentration gradients
chemical gradients
electrical gradients

questions.neutral_comments: Ions are charged molecules or atoms. They will tend to diffuse down their concentration gradient and down their electrical gradient. For example, a positively charged ion will tend to have a net flow towards the side of the membrane that is more negatively charged. If a positively charged ion is in a higher concentration inside of a cell than outside of the cell, the ion may or may not have a net movement to the outside of the cell because the outsides of cells are positively charged relative to their insides. So, whether a positively charged ion would have a net flow to the outside of a cell would depend on how steep its concentration gradient is relative to how steep its electrical gradient is. The bottom line is that the net movement of an ion is down its electrochemical gradient, which takes into account both the tendency for all substances to move down their concentration gradients along with the tendency for positively charged ions to flow towards the more negatively charged side of a membrane and vice versa.

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of carrier proteins in a plasma membrane?

options.text: They are peripheral membrane proteins.
They always exhibit specificity for a particular type of molecule.
All carrier proteins require the expenditure of cellular energy to function.
All carrier proteins work against diffusion.

questions.neutral_comments: Some carrier proteins carry out facilitated diffusion. Facilitated diffusion is diffusion of a molecule down its concentration and/or electrical gradient that is “facilitated” by a carrier protein or channel protein that allows the molecule that is diffusing to pass more quickly through the membrane. Because the molecules being transported are moving down their concentration and/or electrical gradient, carrier proteins that act in facilitated diffusion do not require an energy expenditure. However, other carrier proteins, such as symporters and anti-porters, help carry out active transport and so do require an energy expenditure.

questions.question: Glucose diffuses slowly through artificial phospholipid bilayers. The cells lining the small intestine, however, rapidly move large quantities of glucose from glucose-rich foods into their glucose-poor cytoplasm. Using this information, which transport mechanism is most probably functioning in the intestinal cells?

options.text: Active transport pumps
Facilitated diffusion
Simple diffusion
Glucoport

questions.neutral_comments: The information that glucose diffuses poorly through artificial phospholipid bilayers tells you that glucose will diffuse poorly on its own through cell membranes. Because you are also told that glucose is entering the intestinal cells quickly, this rules out simple diffusion as a possibility. Because glucose is moving down its concentration gradient as it enters the intestinal cells, no energy should be required for its movement which makes active transport of any means in unlikely possibility. “Glucoport” is a made up term, which leaves facilitated diffusion as the most likely possibility. In facilitated diffusion, channel proteins or carrier proteins in the membrane allow specific molecules that do not easily cross membranes on their own to cross membranes rapidly. So, diffusion (which is always a passive process) is “facilitated” by these proteins.

questions.question: Cotransporters

options.text: transport two molecules of the same type (e.g. two sucrose molecules) across the membrane simultaneously
are transporter proteins that function in cooperative groups
transport molecules after binding to a molecule of ATP
transport two different types of molecules, with one moving down its concentration or electrochemical gradient and the other moving up

questions.question: Which of the following is a form of ACTIVE transport?

options.text: Simple diffusion
Facilitated diffusion by a carrier protein
Transport by a cotransporter
Facilitated diffusion by a channel protein

questions.neutral_comments: All types of diffusion are passive processes where molecules move down their concentration and/or electrical gradients. Transport by cotransporters is a form of active transport. Cotransporters work by transporting two different molecules together. One of the molecules being transported is moving down its concentration and/or electrical gradient. The other molecule being transported is moving up its concentration and/or electrical gradient. The energy required to move the molecule that’s moving up its concentration and/or electrical gradient is provided by the molecule moving down its concentration and/or electrical gradient. Example: A cotransporter moving H+ down its electrochemical gradient while moving sucrose up its concentration gradient is using the potential energy that is stored in the form H+ moving down its electrochemical gradient to do the work of moving sucrose up its concentration gradient.

questions.question: Which of the following processes includes all the others?

options.text: transport of an ion down its electrochemical gradient
passive transport
osmosis
diffusion of a solute across a membrane

questions.neutral_comments: Osmosis (= diffusion of free water molecules down their concentration gradient), diffusion of solute across a membrane and transport of an ion down its electrochemical gradient are all forms of passive transport, meaning that they do not require an energy expenditure by the cell.

questions.question: Which of the following membrane activities do NOT require energy from ATP hydrolysis?

options.text: all of these answers are correct
movement of solutes by channel proteins
movement of solutes by co-transporters
simple diffusion

questions.question: Use the diagram below to help answer this question. The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a selectively permeable barrier. This selectively permeable barrier is permeable to water and glucose, but not to sucrose. If you add 1 liter of water, 2 moles of sucrose and 1 mole of glucose to side “A” of the tube, and 1 liter of water, 1 mole of sucrose and 2 moles of glucose to side “B” of the tube, after the system reaches equilibrium, what changes are observed?

options.text: The water level is higher on side A than on side B.
The molarity of glucose is higher on side A than on side B.
The water level is higher on side B than on side A.
The molarity of glucose is lower on side A than on side B.

questions.neutral_comments: Because the glucose molecules can cross the selectively permeable membrane and initially there is a higher concentration of glucose molecules on side B, more glucose molecules will move from side B to side A than from side A to side B. In other words, there will be a net movement of glucose molecules from side B to side A. Because the membrane is not permeable to sucrose, there will be no movement of sucrose molecules. This means that the total concentration of solute molecules (= glucose and sucrose molecules in this example) will become higher on side A than on side B. That means that more water molecules will be interacting with solute molecules on side A than on side B. This in turn means that there will be a lower concentration of free water molecules on side A than on side B. More free water molecules will thus flow through the selectively permeable membrane from side B to side A than from side A to side B. In other words, there will be a net flow of free water molecules from side B to side A. This will raise the water level on side A.

questions.question: Use the diagram below to help answer this question. The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a selectively permeable barrier. This selectively permeable barrier is permeable to water, but not to glucose or sucrose. If you add 3 liters of an aqueous solution containing 2 moles of sucrose and 1 mole of glucose to side “A” of the tube, and 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of sucrose and 2 moles of glucose to side “B” of the tube, the solution in side A with respect to that in side B is

options.text: isotonic
hypotonic
hypertonic
saturated

questions.neutral_comments: Solution A contains 2 moles of sucrose and one mole of glucose in a volume of 3 liters. That means it has a total of 3 moles of solute molecules in a volume of 3 liters, so solution A is a one molar (= 1 M) solution. Solution B has 1 mole of sucrose and 2 moles of glucose in a volume of 1 liter. That means solution B has a total of 3 moles of solute molecules in a volume of 1 liter, so solution B is a 3 molar (= 3 M) solution. Therefore, solution A is hypotonic (has a lower concentration of solute molecules) with respect to solution B.

questions.question: Which of the following factors would tend to increase membrane fluidity?

options.text: a greater proportion of unsaturated phospholipids
a greater proportion of relatively large glycolipids compared with lipids having smaller molecular masses
a lower temperature
a relatively high protein content in the membrane

questions.question: Which of the following would likely move through the lipid bilayer of a plasma membrane most rapidly?

options.text: an amino acid
glucose
CO2
K+

questions.neutral_comments: Amino acids and K+ are charged molecules. They will therefore pass very poorly through the hydrophobic core of a membrane. Glucose molecules have many polar covalent bonds, due to having many hydroxyl groups. So, glucose molecules will also pass poorly through membranes. In contrast, CO2 is a small molecule that is relatively nonpolar and so will pass through membranes with relative ease.

questions.question: Amphipathic molecules

options.text: are only found in membranes
have both hydrophilic and hydrophobic regions
have modified carbohydrates
have both positively charged and negatively charged regions

questions.neutral_comments: Amphipathic molecules have both hydrophilic (“water loving”) and hydrophobic (“water fearing”) regions. For example, the hydrocarbon chains of phospholipid molecules are hydrophobic whereas the phosphate and other parts of the head group of phospholipid molecules are hydrophilic, so phospholipid molecules are amphipathic molecules.

questions.question: Which of the following most accurately describe kinetic and potential energy?

options.text: kinetic energy includes the energy in a stretched rubber band
kinetic energy is due to movement and potential energy is energy that is stored in matter that is not due to movement
kinetic energy includes energy from the attraction of the earth to the moon
potential energy includes energy from molecular movement

questions.question: Energy that goes to increase the entropy of the universe is

options.text: no longer available to perform work
stored as potential energy
lost forever
all of these answers are correct

questions.neutral_comments: According to the 1st law of thermodynamics, energy can be transferred or transformed but can not be created or destroyed. So, energy that is used to increase the entropy of the universe is not lost. However, that energy is no longer available to perform work.

questions.question: The hydrolysis of ATP to form ADP and Pi is

options.text: slightly endergonic
slightly exergonic
highly exergonic
highly endergonic

questions.question: A chemical reaction that has a positive ∆G is correctly described as

options.text: endergonic
exergonic
none of these answers are correct
spontaneous

questions.neutral_comments: Reactions that have a positive ∆G (i.e. reactions where the total free energy of the reactants is less than the total free energy of the products) are known as endergonic reactions. Reactions that have a negative ∆G are known as exergonic or spontaneous reactions.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is representative of the second law of thermodynamics?

options.text: Conversion of energy from one form to another is always accompanied by some gain of free energy.
Cells require a constant input of energy to maintain their high level of organization.
Every energy transformation by a cell decreases the entropy of the universe.
Without an input of energy, organisms would tend toward decreasing entropy.

questions.neutral_comments: According to the 2nd law of thermodynamics the entropy of the universe as a whole is always increasing. Living organisms, such as cells, are able to use energy inputs to maintain a high level of order, and thus a low level of entropy. However, by doing this living organisms cause an increase in the entropy of their surroundings that more than compensates for the decrease in entropy within the organism. So, the total amount of entropy within the universe increases and the 2ndlaw of thermodynamics is not violated.

questions.question: The mathematical expression for the change in the free energy of a system is ∆G = ∆H – T∆S. Which of the following is (are) TRUE?

options.text: ∆S is the change in entropy.
∆H is the change in free energy.
T is the temperature in degrees Celsius.
∆G is the change in enthalpy.

questions.neutral_comments: ∆G = the change in the Gibb’s free energy of the system. ∆H = the change in the enthalpy of the system. T = the temperature of the system in degrees Kelvin (zero degrees Kelvin = -273 °C. Zero degrees Kelvin corresponds to the theoretical temperature at which entropy reaches a minimum). ∆S = the change in the entropy of the system.

questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE for all exergonic reactions in open systems (e.g. a cell)?

options.text: The products have less free energy than the reactants
The products have less entropy than the reactants
The products have less total energy than the reactants
The products have more entropy than the reactants

questions.neutral_comments: By definition, exergonic reactions are reactions that result in a decrease in free energy. Regarding entropy, remember that in an open system, depending on the reaction that occurs, the entropy of the SYSTEM may increase or decrease. However, also remember that, according to the 2nd law of thermodynamics, the entropy of the universe as a whole must always increase. So, if the entropy of the system decreases, that must be balanced by an even greater magnitude increase in the entropy of the rest of the universe.

questions.question: The hydrolysis of ATP: ATP + H2O → ADP + Pi is exergonic, with a ∆G of -7.3 kcal/mol under standard conditions. What is the source of the 7.3 kcal/mol released in this reaction?

options.text: breaking the terminal phosphate bond to form ATP

the difference between the potential energy in the bonds of ATP and the water molecule, minus the potential energy in the bonds of ADP and Pi. In other words: (potential energy in bonds of ATP + potential energy in bonds of H2O) – (potential energy in bonds of ADP + potential energy in bonds of Pi) = 7.3 kcal/mol
the increase in entropy from breaking apart ATP
both the energy released from breaking the terminal phosphate bond and the increase in entropy

questions.question: The mathematical expression for the change in the free energy of a system is ∆G = ∆H – T∆S. Which of the following is (are) TRUE?

options.text: ∆G is the change in entropy.
∆H is the change in free energy.
T is the temperature in degrees Kelvin.
∆S is the change in enthalpy.

questions.neutral_comments: ∆G = the change in the Gibb’s free energy of the system. ∆H = the change in the enthalpy of the system. T = the temperature of the system in degrees Kelvin (zero degrees Kelvin = -273 °C. Zero degrees Kelvin corresponds to the theoretical temperature at which entropy reaches a minimum). ∆S = the change in the entropy of the system.

questions.question: What is the difference, if any, between the structure of ATP and the structure of the precursor of the A nucleotide in RNA?

options.text: The nitrogen-containing base is different.
There is no difference.
The sugar molecule is different.
The number of phosphates is three instead of one.
options.comment: The ATP used to form RNA has three phosphates. Where you may be confused is that, during the process of joining an ATP monomer to a growing RNA chain, two of those phosphates are lost. So, there is only one phosphate per nucleotide in the RNA chain, but the monomers used to form RNA all have three phosphate groups.

questions.question: When chemical, transport or mechanical work is done by an organism, what happens to the heat generated?

options.text: It is transported to specific organs such as the brain.
It is used to power yet more cellular work.
It is used to store more energy as ATP.
It is lost to the environment.

questions.question: Which of the following is a statement of the second law of thermodynamics?

options.text: Every energy transfer or transformation increases the enthalpy of the universe
Every energy transfer or transformation increases the free energy of the universe
Energy cannot be created or destroyed
Every energy transfer or transformation increases the entropy of the universe

questions.question: “Conservation of energy” is another way of stating

options.text: the first law of thermodynamics
that the universe expends as little energy as possible in carrying out fundamental processes
the second law of thermodynamics
the third law of thermodynamics

questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE for all endergonic reactions in open systems (e.g. a cell)?

options.text: The products have more total energy than the reactants
The products have more free energy than the reactants
The products have less free energy than the reactants
The products have less total energy than the reactants

questions.neutral_comments: The definition of an endergonic reaction is a reaction where there is an increase in FREE energy. So, in an endergonic reaction the products of the reaction will have more FREE energy than the reactants used in the reaction. The fact that a reaction is an "endergonic" reaction does NOT tell you what the change in TOTAL energy, as opposed to FREE energy, will be.

questions.question: How do living organisms create macromolecules, organelles, cells, tissues, and complex higher-order structures?

options.text: Living organisms create order locally, but the energy transformations generate waste heat that increases the entropy of the universe as a whole.
The laws of thermodynamics do not apply to living organisms.
Living organisms create order using energy from food molecules.
Living organisms create order by using energy from the sun.

questions.neutral_comments: The 2nd law of thermodynamics states that the entropy of the universe as a whole must increase. If the entropy of a cell decreases, that decrease can be made up for by an even greater increase in the entropy of the environment around the cell, so that the total amount of entropy in the universe increases.

questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE for ALL exergonic reactions?

options.text: If the reaction proceeds there will be a net decrease in free energy.
A net input of energy from the surroundings is required for the reactions to proceed.
The reactions are nonspontaneous.
The products have more total energy than the reactants.

questions.neutral_comments: By definition, exergonic reactions are reactions where the reaction results in a decrease in free energy. In contrast, it is possible for an exergonic reaction to result in an increase in the TOTAL energy of the system. For that to occur, the increase in the total energy of the system must be more than offset by an increase in entropy. Because exergonic reactions are reactions that result in a decrease in free energy, there is no need for an energy input in order for an exergonic reaction to occur.

questions.question: What term is used to describe the transfer of free energy from catabolic pathways to anabolic pathways?

options.text: energy coupling
bioenergetics
feedback regulation
cooperativity

questions.question: Many of the reactions that occur during metabolism are reversible. Given the laws of thermodynamics, how is that possible?

options.text: Even in the same solution, some of the molecules of a particular species may have more energy than others.
These reactions are reversible in theory, but proceed in only one direction so that the laws of thermodynamics are not violated.
The free energy of the system will decrease when the reaction proceeds in one direction, but the total energy of the system will decrease when the reaction proceeds in the other direction.
Energy is used to drive a reversible reaction in one of the two possible directions.

questions.neutral_comments: For a reaction to be a spontaneous reaction, the free energy of the reactant molecules must be greater than the free energy of the product molecules, so that free energy decreases as a result of the reaction. So, if you imagine a reaction where “A” is converted to “B”, the conversion of a molecule of A to a molecule of B will be spontaneous if the free energy of molecule A is greater than the free energy of molecule B. So, if on average A molecules have a free energy of 5 kcal/mole and B molecules have a free energy of 4.9 kcal/mole, the average free energy of a molecule of A will be greater than the average free energy of a molecule of B and therefore the conversion of an average molecule of A to an average molecule of B will represent an exergonic, or spontaneous, reaction. However, what we have to realize is that different molecules of A in a solution will have slightly different free energies and different molecules of B will have slightly free different energies. So, if the AVERAGE free energy of a molecule of B is 4.9 kcal/mole, there may be some molecules of B that have a free energy of greater than 5 kcal/mole. Those molecules of B that have a free energy that is greater than 5 kcal/mole can then be converted to molecules of A via a reaction that will be exergonic (spontaneous). Note that this does NOT mean that the conversion of B to A will occur at as high a rate as the conversion of A to B. If there are only a very small number of molecules of B that have a high enough free energy level to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction, the rate of conversion of A to B will be higher than the rate of conversion of B to A. Eventually, the high rate of conversion of A to B will result in there being enough molecules of B with sufficient free energy to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction that the rate of conversion of B to A will equal the rate of conversion of A to B. At that point, the reaction will have reached equilibrium and both reactions will occur at the same rate (note that, in this example, at equilibrium there will be more molecules of B than of A, but a smaller percentage of the molecules of B will have sufficient free energy to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction). In addition, there is a tendency for reactions to be reversible because there is greater entropy in a mixture of substances than in a pure substance. In other words, a system that contains a mixture of "A" and "B" molecules will have greater entropy than a system that has just "A" or just "B" molecules.

questions.question: Chemical reactions

options.text: always decrease the amount of energy in an open system that is available to do work.
options.comment: Free energy (∆G) increases when endergonic reactions occur. If the energy input that is needed to drive an endergonic reaction comes from outside of the system, the free energy of the system (= the amount of energy available to do work) will increase.

options.text: always decrease the amount of energy in the universe that is available to do work.
all of these answers are correct
always increase the entropy of an open system.

questions.question: “Every energy transfer or transformation increases the entropy of the universe”

options.text: is a statement of the first law of thermodynamics
is true, except for living organisms
is a statement of the third law of thermodynamics
is a statement of the second law of thermodynamics

questions.question: Whenever energy is transformed, there is always an increase in the

options.text: Entropy of the system
Entropy of the universe
Free energy of the universe
Free energy of the system

questions.neutral_comments: According to the 2nd law of thermodynamics: “Every energy transfer or transformation increases the entropy of the universe”. So, the entropy of the universe as a whole is always increasing.

questions.question: A consequence of the 1<sup>st</sup> and 2<sup>nd</sup> laws of thermodynamics is

options.text: that, according to some theories, at some point in the far distant future there will be no more energy in the universe that is available to do work.
that, according to some theories, at some point in the far distant future the temperature across the universe will be ~ constant.
that the total amount of energy in the universe that is available to perform work is always decreasing.
all of these answers are correct

questions.question: Which of the following types of reactions would decrease the entropy of a cell?

options.text: dehydration reactions
catabolism
respiration
hydrolysis

questions.neutral_comments: Reactions, such as dehydration reactions, that result in the formation of one large molecule from multiple small molecules create more order and therefore less entropy. Reactions that break down a large molecule to more than one small molecule (e.g. hydrolysis reactions, respiration, catabolism) create less order in the system and therefore greater entropy.

questions.question: In a particular metabolic pathway, “A” is converted to “B” which is converted to “C”. Which of the following is likely to be TRUE about catalysis of the steps in this pathway?

options.text: It is not possible to know without more information about “A”, “B” and “C”.
Each step in the pathway will likely be catalyzed by the same enzyme.
Some steps in the pathway may be catalyzed by the same enzyme and some steps may be catalyzed by different enzymes.
Each step in the pathway will likely be catalyzed by a different enzyme.

questions.neutral_comments: Different steps in a metabolic pathway are almost always catalyzed by different enzymes. This is because enzymes are very specific for the substrates they will recognize and the reaction they will catalyze using that substrate.

questions.question: The breakdown of polymers to their constituent monomers occurs during

options.text: anabolism
condensation reactions
dehydration reactions
catabolism

questions.neutral_comments: The breakdown of polymers (and other large biological molecules) occurs during catabolism. Anabolism refers to the part of metabolism where larger, more complex molecules are synthesized from smaller, less complex molecules. Many anabolic reactions occur via dehydration reactions, which are one type of dehydration reaction.

questions.question: Are most chemical reactions at equilibrium in living cells?

options.text: most reactions, except those powered by ATP
no
yes
only the exergonic reactions

questions.neutral_comments: At equilibrium, the free energy change is zero and no work can be done. So, a cell where most reactions are at equilibrium would not be able to do enough work and so would be dead. Also, the "products" of reversible reactions are frequently converted to other substances or transported to other cellular compartments before they can be metabolized via the reverse reaction, which also prevents many cellular reactions from reaching equilibrium.

questions.question: The total energy of a biological system is represented by

options.text: temperature (T)
free energy (G)
entropy (S)
enthalpy (H)

questions.question: Living organisms don’t violate the 2<sup>nd</sup> law of thermodynamics because:

options.text: They increase the free energy of their surroundings
They typically increase the entropy of their surroundings
Trick question, living organisms do violate the 2nd law of thermodynamics!
They typically increase their own entropy

questions.neutral_comments: The entropy of a biological system can decrease (and very often does decrease) without violating the 2nd law of thermodynamics, as long as the decrease in the entropy of the system is balanced by an even greater magnitude increase in the entropy of the rest of the universe.

questions.question: What is the term for metabolic pathways that release stored energy by breaking down complex molecules?

options.text: catabolic pathways
anabolic pathways
thermodynamic pathways
bioenergetic pathways

questions.neutral_comments: Catabolic pathways are pathways where complex, energy-rich molecules are broken down (think of a “cat” tearing something up) to smaller, less complex and less energy-rich molecules. Anabolism is the opposite. In other words, in anabolism larger, more complex and energy-rich molecules are formed from smaller, less complex and energy-rich molecules.

questions.question: Spontaneous reactions

options.text: do not require an energy input to occur
always occur, and do not require an energy input
always proceed rapidly
all of these answers are correct

questions.neutral_comments: Spontaneous reactions are defined as reactions that do not require an energy input to occur. However, it is critical to realize that the word “spontaneous” is used in a different way when discussing chemical reactions than when discussing every day life. So a “spontaneous” chemical reaction may proceed very slowly or not at all, if the activation energy barrier for the reaction is high.

questions.question: Why is ATP an important molecule in metabolism?

options.text: It helps drive exergonic reactions.
All of these answers are correct.
It is formed by endergonic reactions.
It provides energy coupling between exergonic and endergonic reactions.

questions.question: The ATP used by the cell for energy coupling

options.text: is identical to one of the four nucleotides used for RNA synthesis.
has three phosphate groups.
All of these answers are correct.
is a high energy molecule due to having unstable covalent bonds

questions.question: The statement “energy cannot be created or destroyed”

options.text: is a statement of the second law of thermodynamics
is a statement of the first law of thermodynamics
is true for closed and open systems, but not for the universe as a whole
is a statement of the third law of thermodynamics

questions.question: Most cells cannot harness heat to perform work because

options.text: heat can never be used to do work.
heat is not a form of energy.
cells do not have much heat; they are relatively cool.
temperature is usually uniform throughout a cell.

questions.neutral_comments: Heat can only be used to perform work where there is a temperature differential. For example, using heat to cause the air in a piston to expand, allowing the piston to do work, only works if the temperature of the air inside the piston is greater than the temperature of the air outside of the piston. Because the temperature across a cell is generally fairly uniform, cells cannot typically use heat to perform work.

questions.question: The synthesis of polymers from their constituent monomers occurs during

options.text: catabolism
all of these answers are correct
anabolism
hydrolysis

questions.neutral_comments: Anabolism refers to the part of metabolism where larger, more complex molecules are synthesized from smaller, less complex molecules. In contrast, the breakdown of polymers (and other large biological molecules) occurs during catabolism. The breakdown of polymers during catabolism often occurs via hydrolysis (“splitting with water”) reactions. Remember a cat tearing up an object to help remember that catalysis is breaking up large molecules to form smaller ones and anabolism is the opposite.

questions.question: Which of the following is a statement of the first law of thermodynamics?

options.text: The entropy of the universe is increasing.
The entropy of the universe is constant.
Energy cannot be created or destroyed
The entropy of the universe is decreasing

questions.question: Which of the following is considered an open system?

options.text: a plant cell with a strong cell wall
an animal cell
a clam
all of these answers are correct

questions.question: Choose the pair of terms that correctly completes this sentence: Catabolism is to anabolism as ________ is to ________.

options.text: free energy; entropy
entropy; enthalpy
exergonic; endergonic
exergonic; spontaneous

questions.neutral_comments: Catabolic reactions are exergonic reactions where large molecules are broken down to smaller molecules that have less free energy than the reactant molecule. Anabolic reactions are endergonic reactions where small molecules are combined to form larger molecules that have a greater amount of free energy than the reactant molecules.

questions.question: Which term precisely describes the cellular process of breaking down large molecules into smaller ones?

options.text: catalysis
catabolism
anabolism
metabolism

questions.neutral_comments: Catabolism is the breaking down of large molecules (think of a “cat”, for “catabolism”, tearing something up). Anabolism is the cellular process by which large molecules are formed. Metabolism refers to both catabolism and anabolism.

questions.question: The amount of disorder or randomness is a system is represented by

options.text: temperature (T)
enthalpy (H)
free energy (G)
entropy (S)

questions.question: Which of the following statements is FALSE?

options.text: Phosphorylation of a molecule usually raises the potential energy of the molecule, making it more energetically favorable for that molecule to undergo spontaneous reactions.
Phosphorylation of a molecule usually makes the molecule less stable.
Hydrolysis of ATP to form ADP and inorganic phosphate is a highly exergonic reaction
Hydrolysis of ATP to form ADP and inorganic phosphate is a highly endergonic reaction

questions.neutral_comments: Exergonic reactions are reactions that result in a decrease in free energy. Exergonic reactions occur when the total free energy of the reactants is greater than the total free energy of the products. ATP molecules have a lot of free energy, more than the ADP produced by their hydrolysis.

questions.question: A consequence of the fact that Gibb’s free energy must decrease in a spontaneous reaction is

options.text: that a given reaction may proceed spontaneously in both directions, due to the fact that different reactant and product molecules will have slightly different energies.
that all reactions may proceed in only one direction unless there is an input of energy into the system to drive the reaction in the other direction.
that all reactions may proceed spontaneously in only one direction.
that all reactions may proceed in only one direction unless ATP is added to the system.

questions.neutral_comments: For a reaction to be a spontaneous reaction, the free energy of the reactant molecules must be greater than the free energy of the product molecules, so that free energy decreases as a result of the reaction. So, if you imagine a reaction where “A” is converted to “B”, the conversion of a molecule of A to a molecule of B will be spontaneous if the free energy of molecule A is greater than the free energy of molecule B. So, if on average A molecules have a free energy of 5 kcal/mole and B molecules have a free energy of 4.9 kcal/mole, the average free energy of a molecule of A will be greater than the average free energy of a molecule of B and therefore the conversion of an average molecule of A to an average molecule of B will represent an exergonic, or spontaneous, reaction. However, what we have to realize is that different molecules of A in a solution will have slightly different free energies and different molecules of B will have slightly free different energies. So, if the AVERAGE free energy of a molecule of B is 4.9 kcal/mole, there may be some molecules of B that have a free energy of greater than 5 kcal/mole. Those molecules of B that have a free energy that is greater than 5 kcal/mole can then be converted to molecules of A via a reaction that will be exergonic (spontaneous). Note that this does NOT mean that the conversion of B to A will occur at as high a rate as the conversion of A to B. If there are only a very small number of molecules of B that have a high enough free energy level to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction, the rate of conversion of A to B will be higher than the rate of conversion of B to A. Eventually, the high rate of conversion of A to B will result in there being enough molecules of B with sufficient free energy to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction that the rate of conversion of B to A will equal the rate of conversion of A to B. At that point, the reaction will have reached equilibrium and both reactions will occur at the same rate (note that, in this example, at equilibrium there will be more molecules of B than of A, but a smaller percentage of the molecules of B will have sufficient free energy to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction).

questions.question: If most metabolic reactions are reversible, why is equilibrium rarely reached for these reactions?

options.text: The enzymes that catalyze these reactions drive the reactions more in one direction than in the other.
Most of the products of the reactions are removed from the system.
Because living organisms increase the entropy of the universe.
The activation energy barrier for the reaction is lower in one direction than in the other.

questions.question: The mathematical expression for the change in the free energy of a system is ∆G = ∆H – T∆S. Which of the following is (are) TRUE?

options.text: ∆G is the change in entropy.
∆S is the change in free energy.
∆H is the change in enthalpy.
T is the temperature in degrees Celsius.

questions.neutral_comments: ∆G = the change in the Gibb’s free energy of the system. ∆H = the change in the enthalpy of the system. T = the temperature of the system in degrees Kelvin (zero degrees Kelvin = -273 °C. Zero degrees Kelvin corresponds to the theoretical temperature at which entropy reaches a minimum). ∆S = the change in the entropy of the system.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of potential rather than kinetic energy?

options.text: an increase in air temperature as a meteor passes through the atmosphere
water flowing in a river
a food molecule
a hockey puck hitting the boards

questions.neutral_comments: Kinetic energy is energy due to movement whereas potential energy is energy that is stored in matter that is not due to movement. So, a food molecule has potential energy as a result of the energy stored in the chemical bonds holding together the atoms that form that molecule.

questions.question: Which of the following is (are) TRUE for anabolic pathways?

options.text: They consume energy to build up polymers from monomers.
They are usually highly spontaneous chemical reactions.
They release energy as they degrade polymers to monomers.
They do not depend on enzymes.

questions.question: If I try to hit a hockey puck, but miss and hit the ice instead, isn’t that a violation of the first law of thermodynamics because my stick is no longer moving and neither is the puck?

options.text: A hockey game is a closed system. The first law of thermodynamics applies to the universe as a whole.
No, because the kinetic energy from the motion of my stick will have been transferred/transformed into increased heat energy in the ice.
None of these answers are correct.
This is a trick question since, of course, I NEVER miss the puck!

questions.question: Entropy

options.text: is a measure of the total energy of a biological system
is a measure of the total energy of a system
is a measure of the energy in a system that is available to do work
is a measure of disorder or randomness

questions.question: Which of the following statements concerning catabolic pathways is TRUE?

options.text: They are usually coupled with anabolic pathways to which they supply energy in the form of ATP.
They are spontaneous and do not need enzyme catalysis.
They combine molecules into more energy-rich foods.
They are endergonic.

questions.neutral_comments: Catabolic pathways are metabolic pathways that result in the breakdown of large biological molecules to simpler molecules. As a result, they increase the entropy of the system. They are also exergonic reactions as the reactant molecules (i.e. the large biological molecules) have greater amounts of free energy than the product molecules (i.e. the smaller molecules that are formed by breaking down the large molecules). Reactions that result in a decrease in free energy are known as exergonic, or “spontaneous”, reactions. Please remember that the fact that a reaction is a “spontaneous” reaction does NOT mean that reaction will occur at a high rate. In fact, the reaction may not occur at all, depending on the height of the activation energy barrier.

questions.question: A reaction has a ∆G of -5.6 kcal/mol. Which of the following would most likely be TRUE?

options.text: The reaction would result in an increase in entropy (S) and a decrease in the energy content (H) of the system.
The reaction would result in products with a greater free energy content than in the initial reactants.
The reaction could be coupled to power an endergonic reaction with a ∆G of +8.8 kcal/mol.
The reaction would result in a decrease in entropy (S) and an increase in the energy content (H) of the system.

questions.neutral_comments: ∆G = ∆H – T∆S. If ∆G is a negative number, the products of the reaction must have a lower free energy content than the initial reactants. Also, in order for ∆G to be negative, it is not possible for ∆H to be positive and ∆S to be negative. The energy released by a reaction can only be used to power a reaction that requires an amount of energy to occur that is less than the amount of energy being released.

questions.question: At zero degrees Kelvin, in theory,

options.text: all of these answers are correct
water will be frozen
entropy will reach a minimum value
you will be frozen

questions.neutral_comments: 0 degrees Kelvin is known as “absolute zero”. It corresponds to the theoretical temperature at which entropy reaches its minimum value. (In classical theory it was considered the temperature at which molecular motion ceases, but we now know that’s not accurate). 0 degrees Kelvin = -273° C, so both water and you would definitely be frozen solid at that temperature!

questions.question: Which of the following is considered an open system?

options.text: food cooking in a pressure cooker
a sealed terrarium
liquid in a corked bottle
an organism

questions.neutral_comments: An open system is a system where energy and matter can enter and leave the system. That is true of an organism, but not of the other choices.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about biological systems is FALSE?

options.text: The entropy of a biological system can decrease
The total energy in a biological system cannot increase or decrease
The total energy in a biological system can increase
The total energy in a biological system can decrease

questions.neutral_comments: Because biological systems are open systems (i.e. they are systems where energy and matter can enter and leave the system), the total energy in a cell may increase or decrease. Similarly, the entropy of a biological system can decrease (and very often does decrease), as long as the decrease in the entropy of the system is balanced by an even greater magnitude increase in the entropy of the rest of the universe.

questions.question: The amount of energy in a system that is available to do work is represented by

options.text: temperature (T)
enthalpy (H)
free energy (G)
entropy (S)

questions.question: Which of the following is most similar in structure to ATP?

options.text: an anabolic steroid
a DNA helix
an amino acid with three phosphate groups attached
an RNA nucleotide

questions.neutral_comments: The ATP molecules used in energy coupling are identical in structure to the ATP molecules used in RNA synthesis. It consists of a sugar (ribose), a nitrogenous base (adenine) and three phosphate groups.

questions.question: The rate of flow of materials through a metabolic pathway can be altered by

options.text: all of these answers are correct
altering the amount of substrate for the reaction
changing the activity level(s) of one or more of the enzymes that catalyze steps in that pathway.
altering the amount of product for the reaction

questions.question: When ATP releases some energy, it also releases inorganic phosphate. What purpose, if any, does this serve in the cell?

options.text: It can be added to other molecules in order to activate them.
It can only be used to generate more ATP.
It is released as excretory waste.
It can enter the nucleus and affect gene expression.

questions.neutral_comments: The third phosphate in ATP is often transferred to other molecules. Because the covalent bond between the phosphate and the rest of the molecule is a high-energy bond, phosphorylation of a molecule raises the free energy of that molecule. Raising the free energy of a molecule makes it more likely that it can participate in exergonic (spontaneous) reactions as a reactant, since it makes it more likely that the combined free energies of the reactant molecules will be greater than the combined free energies of the product molecules.

questions.question: In an isolated system

options.text: neither energy nor matter can leave the system.
matter, but not energy, can leave the system.
energy, but not matter, can leave the system.
heat, but not other forms of energy or matter, can leave the system.

questions.neutral_comments: The definition of an isolated system is a system where neither energy nor matter can enter or leave the system.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes enthalpy (H)?

options.text: the system’s entropy
in biological systems, enthalpy is equivalent to total energy
the condition of a cell that is not able to react
the total kinetic energy of a system

questions.question: Living organisms increase in complexity as they grow, resulting in a decrease in the entropy of an organism. How does this relate to the second law of thermodynamics?

options.text: As a consequence of growing, organisms create more disorder in their environment than the decrease in entropy associated with their growth.
Living organisms create lots of entropy after they die and the molecules in their bodies dissociate, which makes up for the decrease in entropy created while they were alive.
Living organisms do not follow the laws of thermodynamics.
As a consequence of growing, organisms create an amount of disorder in their environment that is equal to the decrease in entropy associated with their growth.

questions.neutral_comments: The decrease in entropy within the organism is more than balanced by an even greater increase in the entropy of their surroundings. So, living organisms do not violate the 2nd law of thermodynamics as the processes carried out by living organisms increase the amount of entropy in the universe as a whole.

questions.question: What is the change in free energy of a system at chemical equilibrium?

options.text: greatly increasing
slightly decreasing
slightly increasing
no net change

questions.neutral_comments: When a system reaches chemical equilibrium, there is no longer a change in the free energy of the system.

questions.question: The mathematical expression for the change in the free energy of a system is ∆G = ∆H – T∆S. Which of the following is (are) TRUE?

options.text: ∆H is the change in entropy.
∆S is the change in enthalpy.
T is the temperature in degrees Celsius.
∆G is the change in free energy.

questions.neutral_comments: ∆G = the change in free energy (also known as Gibb’s free energy, which explains why it is abbreviated by a “G”). ∆H = the change in enthalpy, which in biological systems is equivalent to total energy. T = the temperature in degrees Kelvin. ∆S = the change in entropy.

questions.question: How does energy from ATP allow some of the reactions of anabolism to occur?

options.text: Some of the energy from a high-energy covalent bond in the ATP molecule is used to form a high-energy covalent bond in a substrate molecule.
A phosphate group is transferred from ATP to a reactant molecule, raising the energy level of that reactant molecule.

Energy from ATP is used to increase the potential energy of a reactant molecule, such that the total free energy of the reactant molecules is now greater than the total free energy of the product molecules that would be formed by the reaction.
All of these answers are correct.

questions.question: ATP is formed

options.text: by many exergonic reactions
during many catabolic reactions
during hydrolysis of many biological polymers (e.g. carbohydrates, lipids and proteins)
All of these answers are correct.

questions.question: Which of the following terms best describes the reaction described in the figure below?

options.text: endergonic
allosteric
anabolic
exergonic

questions.neutral_comments: The free energy of the reactant molecules (A and B) is greater than the free energy of the product molecules (C and D). So, the reaction of A and B to C and D will result in a decrease in free energy of the system. Reactions where the free energy decreases are known as exergonic reactions. In contrast, reactions where the free energy increases are known as endergonic reactions. In metabolism, catabolic reactions, which breakdown complex, energy-rich molecules to smaller, less energy dense molecules are generally exergonic. In contrast, anabolic reactions, which require an input of energy to convert small molecules to more complex, energy-rich molecules, tend to be endergonic.

questions.question: During a laboratory experiment you discover that an enzyme-catalyzed reaction has a delta G of -20 kcal/mol. If you double the amount of enzyme in the reaction, what will be the delta G for the new reaction?

options.text: +40 kcal/mole
+20 kcal/mole
-40 kcal/mole
-20 kcal/mole

questions.neutral_comments: Because enzymes do not change the free energy change of a reaction, delta G will still be -20 kcal/mole. Please note that enzymes DO lower the energy activation barrier, which is the energy barrier that reactant molecules must surmount in order for a reaction to occur. But, enzymes do not change the free energy in the reactant or product molecules and thus do not change the difference between the free energies of the reactant and product molecules.

questions.question: For the reaction described in the figure shown below, which of the following represents the activation energy barrier for the noncatalyzed reaction?

options.text: arrow E
arrow B
arrow A
arrow C

questions.neutral_comments: Remember that enzymes act by lowering the activation energy barrier. So, the peak of the red curve represents the energy needed to overcome the activation energy barrier in the non-catalyzed reaction and the peak of the black curve represents the amount of energy needed to overcome the activation energy barrier for the enzyme catalyzed reaction. Arrow “B” thus represents the amount of energy molecules A and B need to gain above their normal, average state in order for the enzyme catalyzed reaction to occur. Arrow “C” represents the amount of energy molecules A and B need to gain above their normal, average state in order for the non-catalyzed reaction to occur.

questions.question: You realize that, for a particular reaction to occur, the molecules participating in that reaction need to have a certain minimum free energy level to get over the activation energy barrier. After measuring the average free energy levels of the potential reactant molecules, you discover that their average free energy levels are a little below that required to surmount the activation barrier. Should you be surprised when you then realize that the reaction is occurring, even though it is only occurring at a relatively low rate?

options.text: No, you should not be surprised because you only measured the average free energy levels of the potential reactant molecules. Some of the molecules likely have more than the average amount of free energy, meaning that they have enough free energy to surmount the activation barrier.
Yes, you should be surprised because the chemical reaction is apparently occurring in violation of the laws of thermodynamics.
Yes, you should be surprised because someone must have published inaccurate data regarding the amount of energy needed to surmount the activation barrier.

No, you should not be surprised because the energy level at the top of the activation barrier represents only an average amount of energy. So, the activation barrier will actually be lower for some of the reactant molecules and higher for others.

questions.neutral_comments: For a spontaneous reaction to occur, the free energy of the reactant molecules must be sufficient to get over the activation energy barrier. If the activation energy barrier is 7 kcal/mol and the average free energy of the reactant molecules is only 6.9 kcal/mole, the average reactant molecule will have insufficient free energy to get over the activation energy barrier. However, we have to consider that only the AVERAGE free energy of the reactant molecules was measured, and that different reactant molecules in a solution will have slightly different free energy levels. So, some percentage of the reactant molecules will have sufficient free energy to surmount the energy activation barrier.

questions.question: If an enzyme is added to a solution where its substrate and product are in equilibrium, what will occur?

options.text: The reaction will change from endergonic to exergonic.
The free energy of the system will change.
Nothing; the reaction will stay at equilibrium.
Additional product will be formed.

questions.neutral_comments: Enzymes do not alter the free energy change of a reaction. Instead, they speed up the rate at which reactions occur by lowering the activation energy barrier. Because enzymes do not change the free energies of the reactant or product molecules, enzymes do not alter the point at which reactants and products will be in equilibrium.

questions.question: Feedback inhibition is used by cells to

options.text: slow down the rate at which organisms excrete waste products.
keep from producing unnecessarily high levels of different products.
decrease the free energy change of undesirable reactions.
slow down the rate at which organisms consume food.

questions.neutral_comments: Feedback inhibition occurs when an end product of a metabolic pathway binds to, and inhibits, one of the enzymes that catalyzes an early step in that pathway. Feedback inhibition is thus used as a mechanism to slow down pathways that are producing product molecules more quickly than they are needed, so that the product molecules are accumulating in the cell.

questions.question: A series of enzymes catalyzes the series of reactions shown below. Product A binds to the enzyme that converts X to Y at a position remote from its active site. This binding decreases the activity of the enzyme. What is substance X?

options.text: a coenzyme
an intermediate
an allosteric inhibitor
a substrate

questions.question: Why do scientists sometimes heat a solution to get a reaction to occur at a higher rate?

options.text: Applying heat causes more disorder in both the reactant and product molecules.
Applying heat causes more disorder in the product molecules, raising their entropy level.
Applying heat raises the average energy levels of the reactant molecules, so a greater percentage of the reactant molecules will have sufficient energy to overcome the activation energy barrier.
Applying heat causes more disorder in the reactant molecules, raising their entropy level.

questions.question: In contrast to non-competitive inhibitors, competitive inhibitors of enzyme activity

options.text: always utilize an enzyme's active site.
can NOT have their effects reversed by addition of more substrate.
cause enzymes to denature.
act allosterically.

questions.neutral_comments: Competitive inhibitors “compete” with substrate molecules for binding to the enzyme’s active site. Addition of more substrate does, therefore, help reverse the effects of a competitive inhibitor by allowing the increased number of substrate molecules to occupy the active sites of more of the enzyme molecules. Because competitive inhibitors bind at the enzyme’s active site, they are by definition NOT allosteric regulators, because the definition of an allosteric regulator is a regulator that binds at a site that is distinct from the enzyme’s active site.

questions.question: A series of enzymes catalyzes the series of reactions shown below. Product A binds to the enzyme that converts X to Y at a position remote from its active site. This binding decreases the activity of the enzyme. Substance A functions as

options.text: a substrate
an intermediate
an allosteric inhibitor
a coenzyme

questions.neutral_comments: Allosteric inhibitors are inhibitors that bind to enzymes at sites that are distinct from the enzyme’s active site.

questions.question: Which of the following metabolic processes can occur without a net influx of energy from some other process?

options.text: amino acids → protein
