ADP + Pi → ATP + H2O

questions.neutral_comments: Three of the reactions shown below result in formation of molecules that have more free energy stored in their chemical bonds than do the reactant molecules. The formation of these molecules (ATP, C6H12O6 and protein) thus requires an input of energy.

questions.question: A solution of protein at room temperature does not readily decompose to form a solution of amino acids because

options.text: Protein hydrolysis is nonspontaneous.
Proteins cannot be hydrolyzed in the presence of so much water.
The hydrolysis of proteins to amino acids is endergonic.
The activation energy barrier cannot be surmounted.

questions.question: An allosteric regulator

options.text: All of these answers are correct.
may increase the activity level of the enzymes it regulates
usually acts on multi-subunit enzymes
may decrease the activity level of the enzymes it regulates

questions.neutral_comments: Allosteric regulators bind enzymes at locations that are distinct from the enzyme’s active site. Allosteric regulators often act on multi-subunit enzymes. The 3-dimensional shapes of these enzymes often oscillate between more and less active shapes. Binding of an allosteric activator to one of the subunits of the enzyme stabilizes all of the subunits in their more active shape. Conversely, binding of an allosteric inhibitor to one of the subunits of the enzyme stabilizes all of the subunits in their less active shape

questions.question: For the reaction described in the figure shown below, which of the following represents the difference between the free energy content of the reactants and the free energy content of the products?

options.text: arrow A
arrow B
arrow E
arrow D

questions.question: For the reaction described in the figure shown below, which of the following best describes the reaction?

options.text: positive ∆G, nonspontaneous
positive ∆G, exergonic
∆G of zero, chemical equilibrium
negative ∆G, spontaneous

questions.neutral_comments: The free energy of the reactant molecules (A and B) is greater than the free energy of the product molecules (C and D). So, the reaction of A and B to C and D will result in a decrease in free energy of the system (i.e. a negative ∆G). Reactions where the free energy decreases are known as exergonic, or spontaneous, reactions.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about enzymes is TRUE?

options.text: Enzymes alter the activation energy barrier for a reaction.
Enzymes alter ∆S for a reaction.
Enzymes alter ∆H for a reaction.
Enzymes alter ∆G for a reaction.

questions.neutral_comments: Enzymes do not alter the free energies of the reactant or product molecules. Thus, enzymes do not alter the ∆G for a reaction. Similarly, enzymes do not alter ∆S or ∆H for a reaction. Instead, enzymes lower the free energy needed for reactant molecules to achieve their transition states, which is another way of saying that enzymes lower the activation energy barrier.

questions.question: The enzyme phosphofructokinase catalyzes the conversion of fructose-6-phosphate and adenosine triphosphate (ATP) to fructose 1,6-bisphosphate and adenosine diphosphate (ADP). Adenosine monophosphate (AMP) activates the enzyme phosphofructokinase (PFK) by binding at a site distinct from the substrate-binding site. This is an example of

options.text: activation by an enzyme cofactor
cooperative activation
allosteric activation
the coupling of exergonic and endergonic reactions

questions.neutral_comments: In this example, AMP is binding to a site that is distinct from the active site that it is regulating, which is consistent with AMP acting as an allosteric activator. Note that this is NOT an example of cooperative activation, as cooperative activation occurs when binding of a substrate molecule to the active site of one of the subunits in a multi-subunit enzyme changes the conformations of the other subunits such that they are able to bind substrate molecules more easily. In this example, AMP is not a substrate molecule and it is not binding to any of the active sites of phosphfructokinase (which does happen to be a multi-subunit enzyme).

questions.question: Kinases are enzymes that catalyze phosphorylation (the addition of a phosphate group) whereas phosphatases are enzymes that catalyze the removal of phosphate groups. A cell can use these enzymes like on-off switches for the activities of various proteins. Which of the following is probably involved?

options.text: a change in the optimal pH at which a reaction will occur
a change in the optimal temperature at which a reaction will occur
changes in a protein’s charge leading to cleavage
changes in a protein’s charge leading to conformational changes

questions.question: The mechanism by which the end product of a metabolic pathway inhibits an enzyme that catalyzes an earlier step in the pathway is known as

options.text: metabolic inhibition
feedback inhibition
noncooperative inhibition
allosteric inhibition

questions.question: If ATP levels decrease and ADP levels increase

options.text: The rates of many anabolic reactions will decrease due to increased allosteric inhibition by ADP.
All of these answers are correct.
The rates of many catabolic reactions will increase due to decreased allosteric inhibition by ATP.
The rates of many catabolic reactions will increase due to increased allosteric activation by ADP.

questions.neutral_comments: Catabolic pathways tend to produce ATP from ADP whereas anabolic pathways tend to produce ADP from ATP. If ATP levels in the cell are high, it makes sense to slow down catabolic pathways as the cell doesn’t need to be producing more ATP at that point. As a consequence, many catabolic enzymes evolved so that they are inhibited by ATP. For a similar reason, many catabolic enzymes are activated by ADP. Conversely, because anabolic pathways require ATP and generate ADP, many of the enzymes that catalyze anabolic reactions are activated by ATP and inhibited by ADP.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about ATP and ADP is TRUE?

options.text: ATP and ADP act as allosteric inhibitors of many enzymes in anabolic pathways.
ATP acts as an allosteric inhibitor of many enzymes in anabolic pathways while ADP acts as an allosteric activator of many enzymes in anabolic pathways.
ATP acts as an allosteric activator of many enzymes in catabolic pathways while ADP acts as an allosteric inhibitor of many enzymes in catabolic pathways.
ATP acts as an allosteric inhibitor of many enzymes in catabolic pathways while ADP acts as an allosteric activator of many enzymes in catabolic pathways.

questions.neutral_comments: Catabolic pathways tend to produce ATP from ADP whereas anabolic pathways tend to produce ADP from ATP. If ATP levels in the cell are high, it makes sense to slow down catabolic pathways as the cell doesn’t need to be producing more ATP at that point. As a consequence, many catabolic enzymes evolved so that they are inhibited by ATP. For a similar reason, many catabolic enzymes are activated by ADP. Conversely, because anabolic pathways require ATP and generate ADP, many of the enzymes that catalyze anabolic reactions are activated by ATP and inhibited by ADP.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about substrate molecules in their transition state is FALSE?

options.text: Molecules in their transition states have increased stability.
Energy is needed to move molecules from their normal to their transition states.
Molecules in their transition states have higher energies than when they are not in their transition states.
Molecules in their transition states are contorted into unusual shapes.

questions.question: For the reaction described in the figure shown below, arrow “C” represents

options.text: The activation energy for the noncatalyzed reaction.
The activation energy for the enzyme-catalyzed reaction.
The decrease in free energy over the course of the reaction
The increase in energy of the products (C and D).

questions.neutral_comments: Remember that enzymes act by lowering the activation energy barrier. So, the peak of the red curve represents the energy needed to overcome the activation energy barrier in the non-catalyzed reaction and the peak of the black curve represents the amount of energy needed to overcome the activation energy barrier for the enzyme catalyzed reaction. Arrow “B” thus represents the amount of energy molecules A and B need to gain above their normal, average state in order for the enzyme catalyzed reaction to occur. Arrow “C” represents the amount of energy molecules A and B need to gain above their normal, average state in order for the non-catalyzed reaction to occur.

questions.question:
Firefly luciferase catalyzes the reaction:



What is the role of luciferase?

options.text: Luciferase makes the reaction irreversible.
Luciferase lowers the transition energy of the reaction.
Luciferase makes the ∆G of the reaction more negative.
Luciferase alters the equilibrium point of the reaction.

questions.neutral_comments: Luciferase is an enzyme. Like all enzymes, luciferase acts by lowering the energy activation barrier necessary for the reaction to occur. As a result, a greater percentage of the substrate molecules will have sufficient energy to surmount the energy activation barrier (i.e. to achieve their highest-energy transition state), allowing the reaction to proceed more quickly.

questions.question: Increasing the substrate concentration in an enzymatic reaction could overcome which of the following?

options.text: allosteric inhibition
competitive inhibition
denaturization of the enzyme
insufficient cofactors

questions.neutral_comments: Competitive inhibition occurs when an inhibitor competes with substrate molecules for binding to the active site of the enzyme. Increasing the concentration of substrate molecules will help them out compete a competitive inhibitor. In contrast, allosteric inhibitors bind to sites on the enzyme that are distinct from the active site. So, increasing the concentration of substrate molecules will not alleviate allosteric inhibition.

questions.question: A solution of starch at room temperature does not readily decompose to form a solution of simple sugars because

options.text: The activation energy barrier cannot be surmounted.
Starch cannot be hydrolyzed in the presence of so much water.
Starch hydrolysis is nonspontaneous.
The hydrolysis of starch to sugar is endergonic.

questions.neutral_comments: The hydrolysis of starch to form sugars is a spontaneous process, meaning that it represents in an exergonic reaction (i.e. a reaction where the free energy of the products is less than the free energy of the reactants). The reason that starch hydrolysis does not occur at room temperature is that the activation energy barrier is too high. The starch molecules do not have sufficient energy to assume the required high-energy transitional state for the reaction to occur in the absence of a catalyst.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding enzymes is FALSE?

options.text: Enzyme activity can be inhibited if the enzyme is bound by a noncompetitive inhibitor.
Enzymes alter the free energy change (ΔG) of the reactions which they catalyze.
Enzyme function is dependent on the three-dimensional structure or conformation of the enzyme.
Enzyme function is dependent on the pH and temperature of the reaction environment.

questions.neutral_comments: The statement that is NOT true is that enzymes alter the free energy change of the reactions which they catalyze. In fact, enzymes do not alter the free energy change of the reactions they catalyze. Instead, they decrease the activation energy needed for the reaction to occur. If the activation energy is decreased, more molecules will have enough energy for the reaction to occur and the reaction will occur more quickly. However, the change in energy for each molecule undergoing the reaction will NOT be affected by the enzyme. Think of it like this: Imagine a bunch of people trying to jump from a bed, over a dresser, onto the floor. If the dresser is very high, not too many people will be able to jump over it and make it to the floor. If you lower the dresser, more people will be able to jump over it and make it to the floor. However, the decrease in potential energy will be the same regardless of the height of the dresser, since the decrease in potential energy is dependent (in this example) on the difference between the starting height of each person on the bed and their final height on the floor, which is not affected by the height of the dresser.

questions.question: You notice that many of the anabolic reactions in a cell have speeded up. Upon further characterization of the cell, you are NOT surprised to find that

options.text: both the ATP and ADP levels in the cell are high.
the ATP levels in the cell are high and the ADP levels are low.
both the ATP and ADP levels in the cell are low.
the ATP levels in the cell are low and the ADP levels are high.

questions.neutral_comments: Catabolic pathways tend to produce ATP from ADP whereas anabolic pathways tend to produce ADP from ATP. If ATP levels in the cell are high, it makes sense to slow down catabolic pathways as the cell doesn’t need to be producing more ATP at that point. As a consequence, many catabolic enzymes evolved so that they are inhibited by ATP. For a similar reason, many catabolic enzymes are activated by ADP. Conversely, because anabolic pathways require ATP and generate ADP, many of the enzymes that catalyze anabolic reactions are activated by ATP and inhibited by ADP. So, if ATP levels are high and ADP levels are low, you would expect anabolic reactions to proceed quickly. If you have trouble remembering the difference between catabolism and anabolism, picture a cat tearing something up to remember that catabolism is the breakdown of large, energy-rich molecules to produce smaller, less energy-rich molecules. Anabolism is the opposite (i.e. production of large, energy-rich molecules from smaller, less complex and less energy-rich molecules).

questions.question: How does a noncompetitive inhibitor decrease the rate of an enzyme reaction?

options.text: by acting as a coenzyme for the reaction
by binding at the active site of the enzyme
by changing the free energy change of the reaction
by changing the shape of the enzyme

questions.neutral_comments: Noncompetitive inhibitors bind at sites that are distinct from the active site of the enzyme they inhibit. Binding of a noncompetitive inhibitor causes the enzyme to change its shape in a way that makes the enzyme less effective at catalyzing the conversion of substrate to product. Just as enzymes do not alter the change in free energy of a reaction, inhibitors and activators of enzymes do not alter the change in free energy of a reaction.

questions.question: If ATP levels decrease and ADP levels increase

options.text: The rates of many anabolic reactions will decrease due to decreased allosteric activation by ATP.
The rates of many catabolic reactions will increase due to decreased allosteric inhibition by ATP.
All of these answers are correct.
The rates of many catabolic reactions will increase due to increased allosteric activation by ADP.

questions.neutral_comments: Catabolic pathways tend to produce ATP from ADP whereas anabolic pathways tend to produce ADP from ATP. If ATP levels in the cell are high, it makes sense to slow down catabolic pathways as the cell doesn’t need to be producing more ATP at that point. As a consequence, many catabolic enzymes evolved so that they are inhibited by ATP. For a similar reason, many catabolic enzymes are activated by ADP. Conversely, because anabolic pathways require ATP and generate ADP, many of the enzymes that catalyze anabolic reactions are activated by ATP and inhibited by ADP.

questions.question: Which of the following statements comparing allosteric regulators and non-competitive inhibitors is TRUE?

options.text: Inhibition by allosteric regulators is irreversible.
Only allosteric regulators bind at a site that is distinct from the active site(s) they are regulating.
Only non-competitive inhibitors bind at a site that is distinct from the active site(s) they are regulating.
Allosteric regulators may increase or decrease an enzyme’s activity level.

questions.neutral_comments: Both allosteric regulators and non-competitive inhibitors bind at a site that is distinct from the active site(s) they are regulating (note that, during a particular form of allosteric regulation known as “cooperativity”, the activator – which in this case is a substrate molecule - binds at one of the active sites of a multi-subunit enzyme and in so doing stimulates binding of substrate molecules at OTHER active sites of that enzyme). Binding of allosteric regulators is reversible, not irreversible. Allosteric regulators can act as activators or inhibitors of enzyme activity, whereas non-competitive inhibitors are always inhibitors of enzyme activity.

questions.question: For the reaction described in the figure shown below, arrow “B” represents

options.text: The activation energy for the enzyme-catalyzed reaction.
The increase in energy of the products (C and D).
The activation energy for the noncatalyzed reaction.
The decrease in free energy over the course of the reaction

questions.neutral_comments: Remember that enzymes act by lowering the activation energy barrier. So, the peak of the red curve represents the energy needed to overcome the activation energy barrier in the non-catalyzed reaction and the peak of the black curve represents the amount of energy needed to overcome the activation energy barrier for the enzyme catalyzed reaction. Arrow “B” thus represents the amount of energy molecules A and B need to gain above their normal, average state in order for the enzyme catalyzed reaction to occur. Arrow “C” represents the amount of energy molecules A and B need to gain above their normal, average state in order for the non-catalyzed reaction to occur.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding enzymes is TRUE?

options.text: Enzymes are permanently altered by the reactions they catalyze.
Enzymes decrease the free energy of a reaction.
Enzymes increase the rate of a reaction.
Enzymes change the direction of chemical reactions.

questions.neutral_comments: Enzymes increase the rate at which a reaction will occur, but do not alter the direction or the free energy change of a reaction. Enzymes are not used up by the reactions they catalyze.

questions.question: Which of the following is the best explanation for how enzymes speed up the rates of reactions?

options.text: Enzymes increase the enthalpy of the reactant molecules.
Enzymes lower the energy required for reactant molecules to reach their transition state. Enzymes do not alter the free or total energies of the reactant or product molecules.
Enzymes increase the energy of the reactant molecules.
Enzymes lower the free energy change of the reaction.

questions.neutral_comments: Enzymes lower the free energy needed for reactant molecules to achieve their transition states, which is another way of saying that enzymes lower the activation energy barrier.

questions.question: High levels of citric acid inhibit the enzyme phosphofructokinase, a key enzyme in glycolysis. Citric acid binds to the enzyme at a different location from the active site. This is an example of

options.text: an enzyme requiring a cofactor.
allosteric regulation.
the specificity of enzymes for their substrates.
competitive inhibition.

questions.neutral_comments: Remember that competitive inhibitors bind to the active sites of enzymes and thus “compete” with the enzyme’s substrate for binding to the active site. In contrast, allosteric regulators bind at a site that is distinct from the active site(s) they are regulating. So, from the information given in the question, we know that citric acid inhibits phosphofructokinase and does so by binding a site that is NOT the enzyme’s active site. The only one of the choices below that is consistent with this information is that citric acid is an allosteric regulator.

questions.question: Vioxx and other prescription nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are potent inhibitors of the cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) enzyme. High substrate concentrations reduce the efficacy of inhibition by these drugs. These drugs are

options.text: competitive inhibitors
feedback inhibitors
allosteric regulators
noncompetitive inhibitors

questions.neutral_comments: Competitive inhibitors act by competing (hence the name “competitive” inhibitor) with substrate molecules for binding at the enzyme’s active site. Because of their mechanism of action, the effects of competitive inhibitors may be alleviated by increasing the concentration of substrate molecules, allowing the substrate molecules to occupy a higher percentage of the active sites of the enzyme molecules. Because high substrate concentrations reduce the efficacy (effectiveness) of NSAIDs, you can thus deduce that NSAIDs are competitive inhibitors.

questions.question: For the reaction described in the figure shown below, which of the following would be the same in an enzyme-catalyzed or noncatalyzed reaction?

options.text: arrow D
arrow C
arrow A
arrow B

questions.neutral_comments: Remember that enzymes increase the rate of a reaction by lowering the activation energy barrier. Enzymes do not change the ∆G for a reaction because they do not change the free energy of the reactants or of the products.

questions.question: The active site of an enzyme is the region that

options.text: binds allosteric regulators of the enzyme
binds the products of the catalytic reaction
is involved in the catalytic reaction of the enzyme
is inhibited by the presence of a coenzyme or cofactor

questions.question: For the reaction described in the figure shown below, which of the following would be the same in an enzyme-catalyzed or noncatalyzed reaction?

options.text: arrow A
arrow D
arrow C
arrow B

questions.neutral_comments: Remember that enzymes increase the rate of a reaction by lowering the activation energy barrier. Enzymes do not change the ∆G for a reaction because they do not change the free energy of the reactants or of the products.

questions.question: How can one increase the rate of a chemical reaction?

options.text: Add a catalyst
Cool the reactants.
Increase the activation energy needed.
Increase the entropy of the reactants.

questions.question: Hair is extremely flammable, so why doesn’t your hair spontaneously burst into flame?

options.text: Burning hair is an endergonic reaction that requires energy from fire to drive it.
The molecules in your hair lack sufficient energy at room temperature to overcome the activation energy barrier for this reaction.
Since your hair is generally a mess, burning it would result in a decrease in the total entropy of the universe, which would be a violation of the second law of thermodynamics.
Burning hair is an exergonic reaction that requires energy from fire to drive it.

questions.neutral_comments: Remember that, although exergonic reactions are also known as “spontaneous” reactions, the fact that a reaction is “spontaneous” does not mean that it will occur quickly or even that it will occur at all. Exergonic, or spontaneous, reactions are defined as reactions where the free energies of the reactant molecules are higher than the free energies of the product molecules. So, if the reaction occurs, there will be a net decrease in free energy. HOWEVER, for a reaction to occur the chemical bonds in the reactant molecules must be “stretched” into higher energy forms, so that the reactant molecules reach what is known as a “transition state”. The free energies of the reactant molecules in their transition states are higher than the free energies of the reactant molecules in their non-transition states. So, the reactant molecules may not have sufficient energy to achieve their transition states. If that is the case, the reaction will not proceed even though the overall effect of the reaction would be a decrease in free energy. Note that adding energy to some of the reactant molecules, so that those molecules are able to undergo the reaction, will result in a release of energy that may result in more reactant molecules having sufficient energy to surmount the activation energy barrier and undergo the reaction, leading to a further release in energy that allows more reactant molecules to undergo the reaction, and so on. In other words, once a reaction gets going, it may keep going. So, once hair catches fire it will continue to burn.

questions.question: You notice that many of the catabolic reactions in a cell have speeded up. Upon further characterization of the cell, you are NOT surprised to find that

options.text: the ATP levels in the cell are high and the ADP levels are low.
both the ATP and ADP levels in the cell are low.
both the ATP and ADP levels in the cell are high.
the ATP levels in the cell are low and the ADP levels are high.

questions.neutral_comments: Catabolic pathways tend to produce ATP from ADP whereas anabolic pathways tend to produce ADP from ATP. If ATP levels in the cell are high, it makes sense to slow down catabolic pathways as the cell doesn’t need to be producing more ATP at that point. As a consequence, many catabolic enzymes evolved so that they are inhibited by ATP. For a similar reason, many catabolic enzymes are activated by ADP. So, if ATP levels in the cell are low and ADP levels are high, you would expect catabolic reactions to proceed quickly.If you have trouble remembering the difference between catabolism and anabolism, picture a cat tearing something up to remember that catabolism is the breakdown of large, energy-rich molecules to produce smaller, less energy-rich molecules. Anabolism is the opposite (i.e. production of large, energy-rich molecules from smaller, less complex and less energy-rich molecules).

questions.question: Some bacteria are metabolically active in hot springs because

options.text: high temperatures make catalysis unnecessary.
their enzymes have high optimal temperatures.
they are able to maintain a lower internal temperature.
their enzymes are completely insensitive to temperature.

questions.question: If an enzyme in solution is saturated with substrate, the most effective way to obtain a faster yield of products is to

options.text: add more substrate.
add more of the enzyme.
heat the solution to 90°C.
add a noncompetitive inhibitor.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a method that cells use to regulate enzyme activities?

options.text: compartmentalization of enzymes in specific organelles
allosteric regulation
cessation of all enzyme formation
noncompetitive inhibition

questions.question: Wood does not burst into flame on its own. Yet, once you start a campfire, the wood continues to burn. What is going on?

options.text: The burnt part of the wood releases ash and smoke, raising the entropy of the system.
The burnt part of the wood releases ash and smoke, raising the entropy of the products of the reaction.

The combustion of wood is an exergonic process. Once you start the wood burning, heat is released by the burning wood. That heat increases the energy of other molecules in the wood, so that they now have sufficient energy to overcome the activation energy barrier and begin to burn as well.

The combustion of wood is an endergonic process. Once you start the wood burning, heat is released by the burning wood. That heat increases the energy of other molecules in the wood, so that they now have sufficient energy to overcome the activation energy barrier and begin to burn as well.

questions.neutral_comments: Remember that, although exergonic reactions are also known as “spontaneous” reactions, the fact that a reaction is “spontaneous” does not mean that it will occur quickly or even that it will occur at all. Exergonic, or spontaneous, reactions are defined as reactions where the free energies of the reactant molecules are higher than the free energies of the product molecules. So, if the reaction occurs, there will be a net decrease in free energy. HOWEVER, for a reaction to occur the chemical bonds in the reactant molecules must be “stretched” into higher energy forms, so that the reactant molecules reach what is known as a “transition state”. The free energies of the reactant molecules in their transition states are higher than the free energies of the reactant molecules in their non-transition states. So, the reactant molecules may not have sufficient energy to achieve their transition states. If that is the case, the reaction will not proceed even though the overall effect of the reaction would be a decrease in free energy. Note that adding energy to some of the reactant molecules, so that those molecules are able to undergo the reaction, will result in a release of energy that may result in more reactant molecules having sufficient energy to surmount the activation energy barrier and undergo the reaction, leading to a further release in energy that allows more reactant molecules to undergo the reaction, and so on. In other words, once a reaction gets going, it may keep going. So, once a piece of wood begins to burn, it may keep on burning.

questions.question: Sucrose is a disaccharide composed of the monosaccharides glucose and fructose. The hydrolysis of sucrose results in

options.text: bringing glucose and fructose together to form sucrose
none of these answers is correct
breaking of the bond between glucose and fructose and forming new bonds using the atoms from water.
production of water from the sugar as bonds are broken between the sugar monomers

questions.neutral_comments: Remember that “hydrolysis” means splitting (lysis) with water (hydro).

questions.question: Which of the following is likely to lead to an increase in the concentration of ATP in a cell?

options.text: an increased flux of cofactor molecules
an increase in a cell’s catabolic activity
an increase in a cell’s anabolic activity
an increased amino acid concentration

questions.neutral_comments: Catabolic reactions are reactions where complex, energy rich, molecules are broken down to smaller, less complex and energy rich, molecules. Some of the energy from catabolic reactions is used to form ATP.

questions.question: For the reaction described in the figure shown below, which of the following best describes the reaction?

options.text: The amount of free energy initially present in the reactants is indicated by arrow “A”.
The amount of free energy released as a result of the catalyzed reaction is indicated by arrow “D”.
The amount of free energy present in the products is indicated by arrow “E”
The difference between arrows “B” and “C” is the activation energy added by the presence of the enzyme.

questions.question: A series of enzymes catalyzes the series of reactions shown below. Product A binds to the enzyme that converts X to Y at a position remote from its active site. This binding decreases the activity of the enzyme. Substance A functions in

options.text: feedback inhibition
noncooperative inhibition
catabolic inhibition
metabolic inhibition

questions.neutral_comments: Feedback inhibition occurs when an end product of a metabolic pathway binds to, and inhibits, one of the enzymes that catalyzes an early step in that pathway.

questions.question: Different enzymes may lower activation energy barriers by

options.text: binding different substrate molecules in a way that brings the substrate molecules close together in the correct orientation for a reaction to occur.
providing an environment that is conducive to the reaction.
stretching substrate molecules towards their transition-state form.
All of these answers are correct.

questions.question: For the reaction described in the figure shown below, which of the following represents the activation energy barrier for the enzyme-catalyzed reaction?

options.text: arrow B
arrow C
arrow E
arrow A

questions.neutral_comments: Remember that enzymes act by lowering the activation energy barrier. So, the peak of the red curve represents the energy needed to overcome the activation energy barrier in the non-catalyzed reaction and the peak of the black curve represents the amount of energy needed to overcome the activation energy barrier for the enzyme catalyzed reaction. Arrow “B” thus represents the amount of energy molecules A and B need to gain above their normal, average state in order for the enzyme catalyzed reaction to occur. Arrow “C” represents the amount of energy molecules A and B need to gain above their normal, average state in order for the non-catalyzed reaction to occur.

questions.question: For the reaction depicted in the figure below, the activation energy barrier for converting C and D to A and B via the enzyme catalyzed reaction is represented by

options.text: arrow A
arrow E
arrow B
arrow C

questions.neutral_comments: Remember that the activation energy barrier is the energy needed for molecules to achieve their highest energy transition state. In this diagram, the average energy of molecules of C + D in their non-transition state is indicated by the bottom of arrow A and the energy of molecules of C + D in their transition state during the enzyme catalyzed reaction is indicated by the top of arrow A. Arrow A thus indicates the activation energy barrier that would need to be overcome for C and D to be converted to A and B via an enzyme catalyzed reaction.

questions.question: When you have a severe fever, what may be a grave consequence if this is not controlled?

options.text: removal of amine groups from your proteins
changes in the folding of enzymes
binding of enzymes to inappropriate substrates
destruction of your enzyme’s primary structure

questions.question: A noncompetitive inhibitor for a particular enzyme

options.text: may be “out competed” for binding at the enzyme’s binding site by adding a higher concentration of substrate molecules.
will have a 3-dimensional structure that is similar to that of the enzyme’s substrate.
will bind to the enzyme’s active site, preventing binding of substrate molecules.
None of these answers are correct.

questions.question: A competitive inhibitor for a particular enzyme

options.text: will be more effective the higher its concentration
will compete with the enzyme’s substrate for binding to the enzyme’s active site
All of these answers are correct.
will have a 3-dimensional structure that is similar to that of the enzyme’s substrate

questions.question: The active site of an enzyme

options.text: all of these answers are correct
is activated by binding of ATP
binds substrate molecules
binds product molecules

questions.neutral_comments: The active site of an enzyme binds substrate molecules. Once the substrate molecules are converted to product molecules, they are no longer bound by the active site. ATP activates some substrate molecules by transferring a high-energy phosphate group to the substrate molecule, but does not generally activate active sites.

questions.question: For the reaction described in the figure shown below, which of the following represents the ∆G of the reaction?

options.text: arrow E
arrow A
arrow C
arrow D

questions.neutral_comments: ∆G, the change in the free energy of the system, is the difference between the free energies of the reactants (A and B) and the products (C and D).

questions.question: How quickly do spontaneous reactions occur?

options.text: It depends on the reaction. Some spontaneous reactions almost never occur.
Somewhat quickly
Very quickly
Extremely quickly

questions.neutral_comments: Remember that, although exergonic reactions are also known as “spontaneous” reactions, the fact that a reaction is “spontaneous” does not mean that it will occur quickly or even that it will occur at all. Exergonic, or spontaneous, reactions are defined as reactions where the free energies of the reactant molecules are higher than the free energies of the product molecules. So, if the reaction occurs, there will be a net decrease in free energy. HOWEVER, for a reaction to occur the chemical bonds in the reactant molecules must be “stretched” into higher energy forms, so that the reactant molecules reach what is known as a “transition state”. The free energies of the reactant molecules in their transition states are higher than the free energies of the reactant molecules in their non-transition states. So, the reactant molecules may not have sufficient energy to achieve their transition states. If that is the case, the reaction will not proceed even though the overall effect of the reaction would be a decrease in free energy. Note that adding energy to some of the reactant molecules, so that those molecules are able to undergo the reaction, will result in a release of energy that may result in more reactant molecules having sufficient energy to surmount the activation energy barrier and undergo the reaction, leading to a further release in energy that allows more reactant molecules to undergo the reaction, and so on. In other words, once a reaction gets going, it may keep going.

questions.question: Which of the following are TRUE for anabolic pathways?

options.text: They are usually highly spontaneous chemical reactions
They release energy as they degrade polymers to monomers
They do not depend on enzymes
They consume energy to build up polymers from monomers

questions.neutral_comments: Anabolic pathways build polymers from monomers. They are endergonic pathways as the free energy of the products (polymers) is greater than the free energy of the reactants (monomers). As a consequence, anabolic pathways are nonspontaneous pathways that require an energy input, such as from ATP, to occur. The reactions in anabolic pathways are catalyzed by enzymes.

questions.question: In a particular reversible reaction, “A” and “B” may be converted to “C” and “D”, or “C” and “D” may be converted to “A” and “B”. The direction of this reversible reaction will be determined by

options.text: None of these answers are correct.
the relative concentrations of “A” and “B” versus “C” and “D”
Both “a” and “b” are correct.
whether the enzyme that catalyzes the reaction catalyzes the forward or reverse reactions

questions.neutral_comments: Enzymes do not alter the free energy change of a reaction and so do not alter the point at which equilibrium will be reached or the overall direction of the reaction. In contrast, the direction of a reversible reaction will be determined by the relative concentrations of the reactants and products of the reactions, together with the difference in the free energies of the reactant and product molecules.

questions.question: If ATP levels increase and ADP levels decrease

options.text: The rates of many catabolic reactions will decrease due to increased allosteric inhibition by ATP.
The rates of many anabolic reactions will increase due to decreased allosteric inhibition by ADP.
All of these answers are correct.
The rates of many anabolic reactions will increase due to increased allosteric activation by ATP.

questions.neutral_comments: Catabolic pathways tend to produce ATP from ADP whereas anabolic pathways tend to produce ADP from ATP. If ATP levels in the cell are high, it makes sense to slow down catabolic pathways as the cell doesn’t need to be producing more ATP at that point. As a consequence, many catabolic enzymes evolved so that they are inhibited by ATP. For a similar reason, many catabolic enzymes are activated by ADP. Conversely, because anabolic pathways require ATP and generate ADP, many of the enzymes that catalyze anabolic reactions are activated by ATP and inhibited by ADP.

questions.question: Wood is extremely flammable, so why don’t trees spontaneously burst into flame?

options.text: The chemical bonds in wood have more potential energy than the chemical bonds in ash.
Burning wood is an endergonic reaction that requires energy from fire to drive it.
Burning wood is an exergonic reaction that requires energy from fire to drive it.
At room temperature, the molecules in wood do not have sufficient energy to overcome the activation energy barrier necessary for this reaction to occur.

questions.neutral_comments: Remember that, although exergonic reactions are also known as “spontaneous” reactions, the fact that a reaction is “spontaneous” does not mean that it will occur quickly or even that it will occur at all. Exergonic, or spontaneous, reactions are defined as reactions where the free energies of the reactant molecules are higher than the free energies of the product molecules. So, if the reaction occurs, there will be a net decrease in free energy. HOWEVER, for a reaction to occur the chemical bonds in the reactant molecules must be “stretched” into higher energy forms, so that the reactant molecules reach what is known as a “transition state”. The free energies of the reactant molecules in their transition states are higher than the free energies of the reactant molecules in their non-transition states. So, the reactant molecules may not have sufficient energy to achieve their transition states. If that is the case, the reaction will not proceed even though the overall effect of the reaction would be a decrease in free energy. Note that adding energy to some of the reactant molecules, so that those molecules are able to undergo the reaction, will result in a release of energy that may result in more reactant molecules having sufficient energy to surmount the activation energy barrier and undergo the reaction, leading to a further release in energy that allows more reactant molecules to undergo the reaction, and so on. In other words, once a reaction gets going, it may keep going. So, once a piece of wood begins to burn, it may keep on burning. To remember the difference between exergonic and endergonic, think of free energy exiting the system during an exergonic reaction (where the free energies of the reactants are greater than those of the products) and entering the system during an endergonic reaction (where the free energies of the reactants are less than those of the products).

questions.question: Succinate dehydrogenase catalyzes the conversion of succinate to fumarate. The reaction is inhibited by malonic acid. Increasing the ratio of succinate to malonic acid reduces the inhibitory effect of malonic acid. What role does malonic acid play in this reaction?

options.text: It is a noncompetitive inhibitor.
It is a competitive inhibitor.
It replaces the usual enzyme.
It blocks the binding of fumarate.

questions.neutral_comments: Competitive inhibitors compete with substrate (succinate, in this case) molecules for binding to the enzyme’s active site. Adding more substrate (e.g. succinate) molecules will alleviate this type of inhibition. In contrast, noncompetitive inhibitors bind to sites that are distinct from the enyzme’s active site. Increasing the substrate concentration does not alleviate inhibition by a noncompetitive inhibitor.

questions.question: Binding of an allosteric regulator to the enzyme it regulates

options.text: is irreversible.
may occur via covalent bonds.
is at the enzyme’s active site.
may occur via ionic bonds

questions.neutral_comments: By definition, allosteric regulators bind enzymes at locations that are distinct from the enzyme’s active site. Binding of allosteric regulators to enzymes is via noncovalent bonds, such as ionic or hydrogen bonds. The binding of an allosteric regulator to an enzyme is always reversible. This is in contrast to noncompetitive inhibitors, which may bind an enzyme via noncovalent bonds and usually bind irreversibly to enzymes. Noncompetitive inhibitors and allosteric regulators do share the trait that they bind at a site that is distinct from the active site they are reuglating.

questions.question: For the reaction depicted in the figure below, the activation energy barrier for converting C and D to A and B via the non-catalyzed reaction is represented by

options.text: arrow C
arrow B
arrow A
arrow E

questions.neutral_comments: Remember that the activation energy barrier is the energy needed for molecules to achieve their highest energy transition state. In this diagram, the average energy of molecules of C + D in their non-transition state is indicated by the bottom of arrow E and the energy of molecules of C + D in their transition state during the non-catalyzed reaction is indicated by the top of arrow E. Arrow E thus indicates the activation energy barrier that would need to be overcome for C and D to be converted to A and B via a non-catalyzed reaction.

questions.question: Which of the following is likely to lead to an increase in the concentration of ATP in a cell?

options.text: a decrease in a cell’s catabolic activity
an increased flux of cofactor molecules
an increased amino acid concentration
a decrease in a cell’s anabolic activity

questions.neutral_comments: Anabolic, or biosynthetic, reactions use energy from ATP to form larger, more complex and energy-rich, molecules from smaller, less complex and energy rich, molecules. So, decreasing the rate of anabolic reactions would decrease the rate at which ATP is being used up, allowing ATP concentrations in the cell to increase.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about enzymes is FALSE?

options.text: Proteins may act as enzymes
RNA molecules may act as enzymes
Enzymes increase the free energy of the reactants.
Enzymes are not used up by the reactions they catalyze

questions.neutral_comments: Enzymes do not alter the free energies of the reactant or product molecules. Instead, they lower the free energy needed for reactant molecules to achieve their transition states, which is another way of saying that enzymes lower the activation energy barrier.

questions.question: The oxidation of glucose to CO<sub>2</sub> and H<sub>2</sub>O is highly exergonic: ∆G = -636 kcal/mol. Why doesn’t glucose spontaneously combust?

options.text: The glucose molecules lack the activation energy at room temperature.
The water molecules quench the reaction.
There is too much CO2 in the air.
CO2 has higher energy than glucose.

questions.neutral_comments: Remember that, although exergonic reactions are also known as “spontaneous” reactions, the fact that a reaction is “spontaneous” does not mean that it will occur quickly or even that it will occur at all. Exergonic, or spontaneous, reactions are defined as reactions where the free energies of the reactant molecules are higher than the free energies of the product molecules. So, if the reaction occurs, there will be a net decrease in free energy. HOWEVER, for a reaction to occur the chemical bonds in the reactant molecules must be “stretched” into higher energy forms, so that the reactant molecules reach what is known as a “transition state”. The free energies of the reactant molecules in their transition states are higher than the free energies of the reactant molecules in their non-transition states. So, the reactant molecules may not have sufficient energy to achieve their transition states. If that is the case, the reaction will not proceed even though the overall effect of the reaction would be a decrease in free energy. Note that adding energy to some of the reactant molecules, so that those molecules are able to undergo the reaction, will result in a release of energy that may result in more reactant molecules having sufficient energy to surmount the activation energy barrier and undergo the reaction, leading to a further release in energy that allows more reactant molecules to undergo the reaction, and so on. In other words, once a reaction gets going, it may keep going.

questions.question: Reactants capable of interacting to form products in a chemical reaction must first overcome a thermodynamic barrier known as the reaction’s

options.text: entropy
endothermic level
activation energy barrier
free-energy content

questions.question: If I have trouble seeing a figure for a question I should

options.text: assume the figure is missing for that question.
re-size my browser window. If that doesn't work I should make sure I'm using Google chrome and have recently cleared the cache from my browser.

questions.neutral_comments: All the figures are present for each question that includes a figure. Sometimes a student may need to re-size their browser window to be able to see a figure for a particular question.

questions.question: In eukaryotes

options.text: the cytoplasm, but not the cytosol, includes organelles and other large structures.
the cytoplasm is the part of the cell between the plasma membrane and the nucleus.
the cytosol is the semi-fluid part of the cytoplasm
All of these answers are correct.

questions.question: Chloroplasts

options.text: are self-replicating.
All of these answers are correct.
are believed to have arisen from symbiotic cyanobacteria (prokaryotes) that somehow survived endocytosis (being engulfed) by another cell.
contain some of their own DNA.

questions.question: Desmosomes function to

options.text: prevent leakage of extracellular fluid between neighboring cells
create spaces between cells
fasten cells together into strong sheets
provide cytoplasmic channels between cells

questions.question: All of the following are part of a prokaryotic cell except

options.text: ribosomes
an endoplasmic reticulum
a plasma membrane
DNA

questions.neutral_comments: Prokaryotes, with rare exceptions, do not have membrane bound organelles, such as endoplasmic reticulum. Please note that ribosomes are NOT membrane bound and are contained by both prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells (as are DNA and a plasma membrane).

questions.question: Which of the following produces and modifies polysaccharides that will be secreted?

options.text: mitochondrion
Golgi apparatus
vacuole
lysosome

questions.question: Mitochondria are sites where

options.text: ATP molecules are formed.
some of the reactions required to complete the breakdown of lipids, resulting in formation of CO2 and H2O, occur
all of these answers are correct
some of the reactions required to complete the breakdown of sugars, resulting in formation of CO2 and H2O, occur

questions.question: If the power of the eyepiece of a microscope is 5 and the power of the objective lens for that microscope is 30

options.text: the microscope will magnify images 150 times
the microscope will magnify images 30 times
the microscope will magnify images 5 times
the microscope will magnify images 6 times

questions.neutral_comments: To determine the magnifying power of a microscope, multiply the power of the eyepiece by the power of the objective lens. So, in this case, the microscope will magnify images 5 X 30 = 150 times.

questions.question: Motor proteins provide for molecular motion in cells by interacting with what types of cellular structures?

options.text: membrane lipids
cellulose fibers in cell walls
cytoskeletons
membrane proteins

questions.question: Which types of RNA molecules are predominantly transcribed in a special region of the nucleus known as the nucleolus?

options.text: all of these answers are correct
mRNA
tRNA
rRNA

questions.question: Under which of the following conditions would you expect to find a cell where the majority of ribosomes in that cell are free ribosomes?

options.text: a cell that is enlarging its vacuole
a cell that is digesting food particles
a cell that is secreting proteins
a cell that is producing cytoplasmic enzymes

questions.neutral_comments: Free ribosomes produce cytoplasmic proteins, such as enzymes, and proteins that end up in the nucleus, mitochondria or chloroplasts. In contrast, bound ribosomes produce primarily secreted proteins and membrane proteins for components of the endomembrane system.

questions.question: Which structure is common to plant and animal cells?

options.text: central vacuole
chloroplast
wall made of cellulose
mitochondrion

questions.neutral_comments: Chloroplasts, cell walls made out of cellulose and large central vacuoles are found in plant cells. In contrast, both plant and animal cells contain mitochondria.

questions.question: Which of the following organelles does NOT have membrane as an important part of its structure?

options.text: Golgi apparatus
mitochondria
endoplasmic reticulum
ribosomes

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the cytoskeleton is FALSE?

options.text: The cytoskeleton acts as a support system for the cell.
The cytoskeleton acts in movement of parts of cells.
For certain cell types, the cytoskeleton acts in movement of whole cells.
Calcium atoms form a major part of the structure of the cytoskeleton

questions.question: Tight junctions function to

options.text: fasten cells together into strong sheets
prevent leakage of extracellular fluid between neighboring cells
create spaces between cells
provide cytoplasmic channels between cells

questions.question: Which of the following is a compartment that often takes up much of the volume of a plant cell?

options.text: nucleus
central vacuole
Golgi apparatus
lysosome

questions.neutral_comments: The central vacuole occupies the majority of the volume of many plant cells.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a component of chloroplasts?

options.text: grana
plasmodesmata
thylakoids
stroma

questions.neutral_comments: Plasmodesmata are membranous pores through plant cell walls. Plasmodesmata connect different plant cells to each other, allowing small molecules to diffuse between cells. Because the vast majority of cells in plants are connected by plasmodesmata, plants have been called “supracellular” organisms, in contrast to multi-cellular organisms and single-celled, or unicellular organisms.

questions.question: Electron microscopes are able to provide better resolution than light microscopes because

options.text: electrons have much smaller wavelengths than visible light
electrons have a lot more energy than photons
electrons are charged particles and photons are neutral
electrons are much more powerful than photons

questions.neutral_comments: The longer the wavelength of the radiation used for imaging, the less possible it is to resolve two structures that are close together. So electron microscopes provide better resolution than light microscopes because electrons have much shorter wavelengths than photons.

questions.question: Which of the following relationships between cell structures and their respective functions is correct?

options.text: cell wall; support, protection
chloroplasts; chief sites of cellular respiration
chromosomes: cytoskeleton of the nucleus
ribosomes; secretion

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the central dogma of molecular biology is TRUE?

options.text: RNA is translated to form DNA and DNA is transcribed to form proteins.
DNA is transcribed to form RNA and mRNA is translated to form proteins.
DNA is translated to form RNA and mRNA is transcribed to form proteins.
RNA is transcribed to form DNA and DNA is translated to form proteins.

questions.question: Approximately what percentage of the cells in your body are human cells?
questions.neutral_comments: Different reports give the percentage of cells in the human body as anywhere from less than 50% to ~ 10%. However, it should be pointed out that, although the majority of cells in our bodies are bacterial cells, because bacterial cells are much smaller than animal (e.g. human) cells, most of the mass of our bodies does consist of human cells.

questions.question: Which pathway is generally followed by a protein produced for secretion?

options.text: Smooth ER, vesicle, Golgi, vesicle
Rough ER, vesicle, Golgi, vesicle
Golgi, vesicle, rough ER, vesicle
Golgi, vesicle, smooth ER, vesicle

questions.neutral_comments: Remember that proteins produced for secretion and proteins that will become part of one of the membranes of the endomembrane system are made by bound ribosomes (= ribosomes bound to the rough ER or nuclear envelope). Proteins made by ribosomes attached to the rough ER are transported via vesicles to the Golgi apparatus where they may be modified. The proteins are next transported via vesicles to their next destination (= the plasma membrane, in the case of secreted proteins). In contrast, “free ribosomes” (= ribosomes that are NOT bound to the rough ER or to the nuclear envelope) produce proteins that float freely in the cytosol or that are transported into the nucleus, mitochondria or chloroplasts.

questions.question: Which of the following are capable of converting light energy to chemical energy?

options.text: peroxisomes
leucoplasts
mitochondria
chloroplasts

questions.neutral_comments: Chloroplasts use light energy to produce sugars, through the process of photosynthesis. Lots of chemical energy is stored within the sugars produced by chloroplasts.

questions.question: Which of the following contains its own DNA and ribosomes?

options.text: peroxisome
lysosome
chloroplast
vacuole

questions.question: Flagella and cilia

options.text: are formed using intermediate filaments
are formed using microfilaments
are formed using microtubules
all of these answers are correct

questions.question: Which structure-function pair is FALSE?

options.text: Golgi apparatus; protein trafficking
ribosome; protein synthesis
lysosome; intracellular digestion
microtubule; muscle contraction

questions.neutral_comments: The components of the cytoskeleton that function in muscle contraction are microfilaments rather than microtubules.

questions.question: If the power of the eyepiece of a microscope is 10 and the power of the objective lens for that microscope is 50

options.text: the microscope will magnify images 50 times
the microscope will magnify images 5 times
the microscope will magnify images 10 times
the microscope will magnify images 500 times

questions.neutral_comments: To determine the magnifying power of a microscope, multiply the power of the eyepiece by the power of the objective lens. So, in this case, the microscope will magnify images 10 X 50 = 500 times.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about plasma membranes is TRUE?

options.text: Only prokaryotic cells have plasma membranes, which act as semi-permeable barriers.
Both prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells have plasma membranes, which function as lipid reserves.
Only eukaryotic cells have plasma membranes, which act as semi-permeable barriers.
Both prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells have plasma membranes, which act as semi-permeable barriers.

questions.question: Which of the following contains hydrolytic enzymes?

options.text: lysosome
chloroplast
mitochondrion
Golgi apparatus

questions.question: Which of the following contains its own DNA and ribosomes?

options.text: mitochondrion
lysosome
peroxisome
vacuole

questions.question: Which of the following are NOT found in animal cells?

options.text: plasmodesmata
gap junctions
tight junctions
desmosomes

questions.question: Which of the following statements about ribosomes is TRUE?

options.text: Bound ribosomes are attached to protein molecules whereas free ribosomes are NOT attached to protein molecules.

Free ribosomes are available to begin synthesizing new proteins whereas bound ribosomes are currently unavailable for synthesizing new proteins as they are already in the process of synthesizing a protein.
Free ribosomes are free to diffuse around the cytosol and bound ribosomes are confined inside the nucleus.
Free ribosomes carry out protein synthesis while floating free in the cytosol and bound ribosomes carry out protein synthesis while attached to a membrane.

questions.neutral_comments: The terms “free” and “bound” apply to ribosomes that are floating free in the cytoplasm or are bound to the rough endoplasmic reticulum. Bound ribosomes will generally be in the process of forming a polypeptide, as the reason they are bound (attached) to the rough ER is because they are attached to the protein they are synthesizing and the protein they are synthesizing is attached to the rough ER. In contrast, a free ribosome may or may not be in the process of forming a polypeptide molecule at any given time.

questions.question: Why have plants been referred to as “supracellular” organisms?

options.text: Plant cells are able to carry out photosynthesis.
The vast majority of the cells in a plant are connected by plasmodesmata, forming a sort of “super cell”
The cell walls surrounding plant cells make them super strong.
Plant cells tend to be larger than animal cells.

questions.neutral_comments: Unicellular organisms are organisms that have only a single cell. Multi-cellular organisms, such as people, are organisms that have multiple cells. Plants have been referred to as “supracellular” organisms because almost all of the cells in a plants are directly connected by pores that run through their cell walls. These pores are called plasmodesmata. Plasmodesmata allow small molecules to diffuse between different cells in a plant without having to cross a plasma membrane. So, most of the cells in a plant can be thought of as being joined together in a giant “super cell”.

questions.question: The wavelength of light

options.text: limits the magnifying power of light microscopes
limits the contrast of light microscopes
all of these answers are correct
limits the resolution of light microscopes

questions.neutral_comments: The longer the wavelength of the radiation used for imaging, the less possible it is to resolve two structures that are close together. The ability of light microscopes to resolve structures is thus limited by the wavelength of light. You could use a light microscope to view images at really high magnifications, but that wouldn’t be useful because the images would just become more and more blurry as the magnification increased.

questions.question: How many covalent bonds do oxygen atoms need to form with other atoms to complete their valence shell?
questions.neutral_comments: Oxygen atoms have 6 electrons in their valence shell, which is the 2nd electron shell. The total number of electrons needed to fill the 2ndelectron shell is 8, so oxygen needs to form 2 covalent bonds with other atoms so that it has 2 pairs of electrons that it is sharing via covalent bonds and 2 pairs of electrons that it is not sharing, for a total of 4 pairs of electrons, or 8 total electrons.

may have only certain average distances from the nucleus but may have any energy level

questions.neutral_comments: The energy level of an electron is dependent on its distance from the nucleus. Electrons may have only certain average distances from the nucleus and only certain energy levels.

questions.question: How many more electrons do hydrogen atoms need to complete their valence shell?
questions.neutral_comments: Hydrogen atoms have 1 electron. This electron goes in the 1stelectron shell. There is only one orbital in the 1st electron shell. Every electron orbital can have a maximum of 2 electrons. So, the maximum number of electrons that can go in the 1st electron shell, and thus the total number of electrons needed to fill the 1st electron shell, is 2. Since hydrogen has 1 to start with, it needs 1 more electron to fill its valence shell.

questions.question: Which structure is the site of the synthesis of protein that may be exported from the cell?

options.text: Golgi vesicles
mitochondrion
rough endoplasmic reticulum
smooth endoplasmic reticulum

questions.neutral_comments: Secreted proteins are synthesized by ribosomes bound to the rough endoplasmic reticulum. Remember that the rough ER gets its name from the fact that it has a “rough” appearance when looked at using a microscope. The reason is has a “rough” appearance is because of the ribosomes that are bound to it. After proteins destined for export are synthesized by ribosomes bound to the rough ER, vesicles bud off of the rough endoplasmic reticulum and transport those proteins to the Golgi apparatus where they are modified. Vesicles than bud off of the Golgi apparatus and transport the proteins to the plasma membrane. The vesicles fuse with the plasma membrane, releasing the proteins to the outside of the cell.

questions.question: Of the following, which cell structure would likely be most easily visualized using a high quality light microscope?

questions.question: Why do grocery stores spray vegetables with water?

options.text: The cells of the vegetables will absorb water and expand against their cell walls, making the vegetables crisper.
The water will be hypotonic relative to the interacellular fluid of the vegetables, allowing the cells to excrete excess ions
The water will help keep the vegetable’s cell membranes fluid.
The water will be hypertonic relative to the intracellular fluid of the vegetables, allowing the cells to lose excess water.

questions.neutral_comments: Water will be hypotonic compared with the fluid inside the vegetable cells. That means there will be a lower concentration of free water molecules inside the vegetable cells, leading to a net flow of water molecules from outside to inside of the cells. This will cause the cells to expand against their cell walls, making the vegetables crisper.

questions.question: Why would a doctor inject a dilute salt solution rather than pure water into the bloodstream of a patient who has suffered severe blood loss?

options.text: Because pure water might cause the patient’s red blood cells to burst.
Because salt will assist in co-transport of needed nutrients into the patient’s cells.
Because salt will help prevent bacterial infections.
Because pure water might cause the patient’s red blood cells to shrink.

questions.neutral_comments: Pure water, which by definition contains no solutes, will be hypotonic compared to the solution inside of the patient’s red blood cells, which contain lots of solutes. That means that adding pure water to the patient’s blood stream will cause there to be more water molecules interacting with solute molecules inside of the red blood cells than outside. That in turn means that there will be fewer free water molecules inside of the patient’s red blood cells than outside of them. Water will thus flow into the red blood cells, causing the cells to swell and possibly burst. So, the doctor uses a dilute salt solution to avoid this problem.

questions.question: According to the fluid mosaic model of cell membranes, which of the following statements about membrane phospholipids is TRUE?

options.text: They can move laterally along the plane of the membrane.
They have hydrophilic tails in the interior of the membrane.
They frequently flip-flop from one side of the membrane to the other.
The occur in an uninterrupted bilayer, with membrane proteins restricted to the surface of the membrane.

questions.neutral_comments: Membrane phospholipids can move laterally in the plane of the membrane but it is rare for them to flip-flop from one side of the membrane to the other because that would require that their phosphate head group, which is quite hydrophilic, pass through the hydrophobic core of the membrane that is formed by the fatty acid chains of the phospholipids. Membrane proteins occur in a “mosaic” and may be embedded in the membrane (integral membrane proteins) or attached to its surface (peripheral membrane proteins).

questions.question: The presence of cholesterol in the plasma membranes of some animals

options.text: acts in transport of water molecules across the phopholipid bilayer
enables the animal to add hydrogen atoms to unsaturated phospholipids.
enables the animal to remove hydrogen atoms from saturated phospholipids.
enables the membrane to stay fluid more easily when cell temperature drops.

questions.neutral_comments: The effects of cholesterol on membrane fluidity are somewhat complicated. At normal body temperatures (i.e. about 98.6°F), cholesterol interacts with phospholipid molecules, restricting their movement and thereby making the membranes less fluid. However, as the temperature drops, cholesterol molecules interfere with the tight packing of the hydrocarbon chains of the phospholipid molecules, making the membranes more fluid (i.e. decreasing the temperature at which membranes lose a lot of their fluidity and so become less functional).

questions.question: Studies have shown which of the following to be a particularly effective way for most students to learn new material?

options.text: repeatedly going over their notes about the material
repeatedly going back over textbook readings about the material
repeatedly answering questions about the material

questions.neutral_comments: In one study, different groups of students were shown a list of vocabulary words. The students were then divided into three groups. The first group of students kept studying (reading over) the list of vocabulary words. The second group alternated between reading over the list of words and being tested on them. The third group kept being tested on the list of words. The first group of students did the worst on tests of the vocabulary words. Interestingly, the second and third groups of students did about equally well. This study suggests that repeatedly going over and over study questions is generally a more effective method of learning new material than repeatedly going over the reading (either from the textbook or from your notes). (And, going over your notes is likely to be more effective than going over the textbook).

questions.question: Which of the following is a true statement regarding recommend priorities in studying for BIOL 1009?

Your primary focus should be on the material covered in the recordings and handouts. For most students, the best way to master this material is to spend a large percentage of their study time on answering the study questions.

Your primary focus should be on the material covered in the textbook. For most students, the best way to master this material is to spend a large percentage of their study time on reading the handouts over and over.

Your primary focus should be on the material covered in the recordings and handouts. For most students, the best way to master this material is to spend a large percentage of their study time on reading the handouts over and over.

questions.neutral_comments: It is highly recommended that students focus on mastering the material covered in the recordings and handouts and focus a lot less on the material covered in the textbook. Although the textbook is a useful resource for learning the course material, it contains a LOT of material, more than what students are typically expected to learn. The material that will be the focus of the quizzes and exams is covered in the recordings and handouts. Therefore, focusing on the material covered in the recordings and handouts is the most efficient way to prepare to do well on quizzes and exams. Studies show that, for most students, the most effective way to master this material is by answering questions, such as study questions.

questions.question: When a reversible chemical reaction reaches equilibrium,

options.text: the forward and reverse reactions stop
the relative concentrations of reactants and products continues to change
the concentrations of reactants and products are equal
the forward and reverse reactions occur at the same rate

questions.neutral_comments: At equilibrium, the forward and reverse reactions occur at the same rate. This does not mean that the concentrations of reactants and products are equal. Typically one will be significantly higher than the other. But, the relative concentrations of the reactants and products will cease to change. For example, if A and B are converted to C and D, and C and D are converted to A and B in the reverse reaction, then equilibrium is reached when the rate of conversion of A and B to C and D is the same as the rate of conversion of C and D to A and B. If the reaction of A and B to form C and D is more energetically favorable than the reaction of C and D to form A and B, equilibrium may not be reached until the concentrations of C and D are significantly higher than the concentrations of A and B. At that point, even though individual molecules of A and B may be more likely to react to form molecules of C and D, because there are so many more molecules of C and D the rate at which molecules of C and D are converted to A and B becomes the same as the rate at which molecules of A and B are converted to C and D. For example, imagine a test tube in which there are 1,000 molecules each of A and B and that 10% of them interact per minute to form C and D. That would mean that the rate of conversion of A and B to C and D is 100 per minute. If the there are 10,000 molecules each of C and D in the test tube and 1% of them react per minute to form A and B, the rate of conversion of C and D to A and B would also be 100 per minute, indicating that the system is at equilibrium. If you removed some of the molecules of C and D from the test tube, right after you removed the C and D the rate of conversion of A and B to C and D would be unchanged, but the rate of conversion of C and D would decrease. So, the system would no longer be at equilibrium as the rate of conversion of A and B to C and D would be higher than the rate of conversion of C and D to A and B. Because of this, the relative concentrations of A and B versus C and D would also be changing, with C and D increasing relative to A and B. Eventually, the concentrations of C and D would increase enough and the concentrations of A and B would decrease enough so that the rates of the forward and reverse reactions would become equal, meaning that equilibrium would be re-established.

questions.question: When an electron is moved further from the nucleus

options.text: its potential energy may change, depending on how the electron was moved
its potential energy is unchanged
it loses potential energy
it gains potential energy

questions.neutral_comments: The further an electron is from the nucleus, the greater its potential energy. Think of it this way. Negatively charged electrons are attracted to the positively charged protons in the nucleus. So, it takes work to increase the separation between an electron and the nucleus. Some of the energy spent in doing this work is stored in the form of increasing the potential energy of the moved electron. This is conceptually similar to increasing the potential energy of a ball by carrying it higher up a hill.

questions.neutral_comments: The nuclear envelope is comprised of two membranes, the inner and outer membranes. Mitochondria also have outer and inner membranes. Chloroplasts typically have three membranes, the outer membrane, the inner membrane and the thylakoid membrane. In contrast, the endoplasmic reticulum has only a single membrane.

questions.question: If a modern electron microscope (TEM) can resolve biological images to the nanometer level, which is much better than the best light microscopes, this is due to which of the following?

options.text: Electron microscopes have much larger objective lenses.
The focal length of the electron microscope is significantly longer.
Electron beams have much shorter wave lengths than visible light.
Contrast is enhanced by staining with atoms of heavy metal.

questions.neutral_comments: Resolving power is limited by the wavelength of the radiation used for imaging. The longer the wavelength of the radiation used for imaging, the poorer the resolution. Because electrons have much shorter wavelengths than visible light, electron microscopes have better resolutions than light microscopes.

questions.question: Which statement correctly characterizes bound ribosomes?

options.text: Bound ribosomes are enclosed in their own membrane.
Bound and free ribosomes are structurally different.
All of these answers are correct.
Bound ribosomes generally synthesize membrane proteins and secretory proteins.

questions.neutral_comments: Bound and free ribosomes are structurally the same. Bound ribosomes are ribosomes that are in the process of synthesizing proteins that are attached to the endoplasmic reticulum. These bound ribosomes are thus linked to the endoplasmic reticulum while they are synthesizing these proteins. Free ribosomes are synthesizing cytosolic proteins.

questions.question: Free energy (G)

options.text: is a measure of the total energy of a biological system
is a measure of the energy in a system that is available to do work

questions.question: How does a noncompetitive inhibitor decrease the rate of an enzyme reaction?

options.text: by changing the free energy of the reactants
by changing the free energy of the reaction
by increasing the activation energy barrier of the reaction
by changing the free energy of the products

questions.neutral_comments: Enzymes work by altering the activation energy barrier of reactions. Enzymes do not alter the free energies of reactant or product molecules and thus do not alter the change in free energy that occurs as a result of the reaction. Because enzymes do not alter the free energies of reactant or product molecules and thus do not alter the change in free energy that occurs as a result of the reaction, the factors that alter enzyme activities (e.g. noncompetitive inhibitors) also do not do these things. Instead, a non-competitive inhibitor makes it more difficult for an enzyme to lower the activation energy barrier. In other words, the activation energy barrier in the presence of enzyme + noncompetitive inhibitor is higher than in the presence of enzyme alone.

questions.question: Anabolism results in the production of molecules with high amounts of potential energy stored in their chemical bonds. How can the reactions of anabolism occur without violating the requirement that all reactions must result in a decrease in free energy?

options.text: B) Energy from ATP is often used to help combine an exergonic reaction with a reaction that would otherwise be endergonic.
D) None of these answers are correct.
A) A reaction that would otherwise be endergonic is combined with an exergonic reaction. The overall reaction than occurs in multiple steps, each of which involves an exergonic reaction.
C) Both A and B are correct.

questions.question: If ATP levels increase and ADP levels decrease

options.text: The rates of many catabolic reactions will decrease due to decreased allosteric activation by ADP.
All of these answers are correct.
The rates of many catabolic reactions will decrease due to increased allosteric inhibition by ATP.
The rates of many anabolic reactions will increase due to increased allosteric activation by ATP.

questions.neutral_comments: Catabolic pathways tend to produce ATP from ADP whereas anabolic pathways tend to produce ADP from ATP. If ATP levels in the cell are high, it makes sense to slow down catabolic pathways as the cell doesn’t need to be producing more ATP at that point. As a consequence, many catabolic enzymes evolved so that they are inhibited by ATP. For a similar reason, many catabolic enzymes are activated by ADP. Conversely, because anabolic pathways require ATP and generate ADP, many of the enzymes that catalyze anabolic reactions are activated by ATP and inhibited by ADP.

questions.question: An example of a hydrogen bond is the bond between:

options.text: the H of one water molecule and the O of another water molecule
C and H in methane (CH4)
Mg+ and Cl- in MgCl2
the two hydrogen atoms in a molecule of hydrogen gas (H2)

questions.neutral_comments: A hydrogen bond forms when a hydrogen covalently bonded to one electronegative atom (such as the oxygen atom in a water molecule) is also attracted to another electronegative atom (such as the oxygen atom in a second water molecule). The pair of electrons shared by the hydrogen atom and the oxygen atom to which the hydrogen atom is covalently bound will spend more time near the nucleus of the oxygen atom than near the nucleus of the hydrogen atom, as oxygen is more electronegative than hydrogen (meaning that oxygen atoms attract electrons more strongly than hydrogen atoms). As a result, the hydrogen atom will have a slight positive charge and the oxygen atom will have a slight negative charge. The slightly positively charged hydrogen atom will then be attracted to the slight positively charged oxygen of another water molecule, forming a hydrogen bond.

questions.question:
Use the diagram below to help answer this question. The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a semi-permeable barrier. This semi-permeable barrier is permeable to water and to Mg++ and Na+ ions, but not to Cl- ions. If you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of MgCl2
to side “A” and you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of NaCl to side “B”, at equilibrium

options.text: there will have been a net flow of water from side “A” to side “B”
there will have been no movement of water molecules across the membrane
there will have been a net flow of water from side “B” to side “A”
there will have been no net flow of water between the two sides of the tube

questions.neutral_comments: MgCl2 and NaCl are both salts that will dissociate into their constituent ions when they come in contact with water. So, the 1 mole of MgCl2 will dissociate to form 1 mole of Mg++ and 2 moles of Cl- and the 1 mole of NaCl will dissociate to form 1 mole of Na+ and 1 mole of Cl-. That means that, immediately after the solutions are added to the two sides of the tube, there will be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B. Importantly, there will be a higher concentration of Cl- (which can’t pass the membrane) on side A than on side B. As a result, there will be more free water molecules on side B than on side A. So, there will be a net flow of water molecules from side B to side A, until the concentration of free water molecules is the same on both sides of the membrane. At that point, free water molecules will still cross the membrane, but the rate at which free water molecules cross from side B to side A will be equal to the rate at which free water molecules cross from side A to side B.

questions.question: How many more electrons do oxygen atoms need to complete their valence shell?
questions.neutral_comments: Oxygen atoms have 8 electrons. 2 of those electrons fill the 1stelectron shell and the other 6 fill 6 of the 8 spots in the 2ndelectron shell, which is outermost shell and thus the valence shell for oxygen. Oxygen thus needs 2 more electrons to fill its valence shell.
